Spoilers herein.I maintain that actors and filmmakers are often at odds. They simply have different concerns. The actor is usually interested in the immediacy of the moment, in pumping life into the project. The director is interested in moving that life with purpose using mechanisms outside the real of the actor: the eye, the flow, the memory. Usually, when you put an actor in charge, all you get is energy spurting all over the place; no form, no way into your soul; no life-altering opportunity, no art.A few of the good actors have crossed that line. Sean Penn and Tim Robbins have impressed me in both roles. Brando and Depp did some really quirky, risky stuff as directors. But Deniro and Redford are worse than bad, they take away from the film life, they cheapen the masters by copying without understanding, they dull our imagination.This film has lots of enveloping music; lots of cloying narrativeover -- both tricks of a poor director. It is excessively simple, and simply presented. Oddly, the only actor who transcends the limits of the gangster film is Pesci in the last few seconds with a pause.The episodes do not connect. They begin and end as if the writer wanted to close the thought by the end of his writing day,Deniro isn't stupid; he knows he messed up. You won't see him direct again.Ted's evaluation: 1 of 4 -- You can find something better to do with this part of your life.

reviews.review_title: I know I'm funny, but I'm not that funny.
reviews.content: What a wonderful directorial debut from Robert De Niro. And what an amazing role he played. I'm always used to see him as a gangster in the mob films, but seeing him as a hard working father in this mob film is a delight to watch. And also, this film is loosely based on the childhood days of Chazz Palmenteri (who played Sonny in the film), who also wrote the screenplay of the film which was based on his play.This is one of the best coming-of-age crime drama which has all the great elements to be a wonderful mob film. The acting, the story, casting and also the direction is all really great. This film so has many great lesson to learn. (Is it better to be loved or feared?: this is one of the best piece of advice that I've heard in a mob film and one of the best in films, general), however, it is inspired by 'The Great Machiavelli'. A Bronx Tale deals with how one is shaped by their upbringing and environment. A great story told in a brilliant way. I also loved the narration in the film. This film has many great scenes which I think is excellent. That makes this film a wonderful piece.Remarkable writing and great direction. And also, this film has one phenomenal screenplay. De Niro's effort on direction is successful. De Niro does a skilled job in character development. With this film directed by De Niro, there are obvious influences from Martin Scorsese, but but I think this film holds up very well on its own and its message of morals and consequences is something very few films has mastered like this one.9.5/10.

The first hour of this movie is pretty good. De Niro is good as a hardworking bus-driver dad, Chazz Palminteri makes a good local mobster, and the kid actor for Calogero is good as well. The gangsters seem a bit romanticized, and the imitation of Scorcese is fairly obvious, but its not bad. Basically it centers around the battle over the kid's affections between the mob boss and his dad, and between the lure of glamorous gangster life and his dad's honest hard work. There's also very entertaining scene of a bar brawl between mobsters and bikers.Is it just me, or did the movie become much less convincing during the second half? C has a romance with a black girl, which could have been fine, but it starts in an abrupt, unconvincing "love at first sight" fashion and turns into a preachy morality tale that reminded me of an after-school special, while C's moronic racist friends meet a deserved ugly end. And I'm sorry, Mr. Mob Boss is not that convincing as an enlightened source of fatherly wisdom.Anyway, the movie struck me as Scorcese-lite, good at first but with a Degrassi High-ish ending.

Robert De Niro directs and stars in this 1993 crime drama that co-stars Chazz Palminteri and Lillo Brancato based on Palminteri's play. This mainly takes place in the 1960's where we meet teen, Calogero aka C (Brancato) who befriends neighborhood mobster, Sonny (Palminteri) who becomes a father figure to him. De Niro (Goodfellas, Heat) plays C's father, Lorenzo who works as a bus driver and wants only the best for his son. He starts resenting Sonny because C spends more time with him and doesn't want him mixed in his kind of business. Eventually, Lorenzo comes to terms with their friendship and C also finds romance with girl, Jane (Taral Hicks). Joe Pesci (Goodfellas, Casino) also makes an appearance. This is a great film, De Niro and Palminteri are terrific in it as usual and the film truly depicts the time of racial tensions and classic music. I recommend this.

reviews.review_title: I usually don't like crime movies, but this is one of those rare exceptions.
reviews.content: This film pushes the boundaries of the crime genre. It has great character development, tons of moral dilemmas that all work really well, fantastic social commentary and even some philosophy. Yes, a gangster flick with philosophy in it, I don't even remember if I ever seen anything similar before. Characters are extremely well written, each with a distinguashable persona and very different moralities. The relations between them are so fleshed out. The characters do learn from each other a lot and even the enemies instead of fighting with each other, they learn from each other's mistakes to improve on their own flaws, that's so impressive and inovative. The film is full of thought-provoking dialogue too, many of the conversations have deep messages in them.I guess the film does rely on questionable plot-devices and unnatural sequences a lot, but the film hits so strong on all the moral dilemmas and astonishing philosophy that I can easily overlook its minor flaws. Martin Scorsese could learn a lot from movies like this.

Robert De Niro's directorial debut makes more than a passing nod to his mentor Scorcese.  And he proves not incapable, the film is nicely shot and cleverly laced with a cool de-wop soundtrack (though the stark combination of lovely music and horrendous violence, effective the first time, grows weary by its third outing).  A slightly predictable story of Italian-American life is offset by a more interesting portrait of racial segregation and changing times; and Chazz Palminteri is great as the boss. Unfortunately, the film remains somewhat schematic in feel, probably because it never quite trusts itself: a persistent narrative voice leads you through this tale, but leaves little scope for your own imagination. But then I thought that about Goodfellas too...

It's refreshing to see a gangster film that, for once, isn't centered around graphic violence and excessive bloodshed. As much as I do enjoy the more violent gangster classics, there is something about a well-told and uplifting story like that of 'A Bronx Tale' that can be just as rewarding for the viewer. This film is far more simplistic and understated than most gangster pictures, whilst at the same time delivering a powerful message.Robert De Niro gives a great on-screen performance, as he always does in these types of films, as well as an impressive directorial debut. The film delves a lot deeper into the mafia world and offers a different perspective to the majority of gangster films. It's a refreshing, highly enjoyable watch and a film I will definitely remember. 'A Bronx Tale' is a very good film all round, highly recommended for everybody who enjoys a good story and not just fans of this genre.
Cried three times. This is a true film. Beautiful.

a strange case of what- to be kind- is unintentional plagiarism; consider goodfellas, the first sections, out in 1990, and this one 3 years later; goodfellas tracks a kid growing up near a mafia club-hangout; so does bronx tale; goodfellas show the conflict of the kid facing strict parents who don't want him associating with the hoods; so does bronx tale; the kid grows up enamored of the local mafia boss in goodfellas, geez what a surprise, so does bronx tale; etc.; also, kid in goodfellas was a natural; little kid in brox tale is too little and too wussy to have meaning, and actor who plays him as a teen has no stage presence, a monolithic expression and delivery; finally- if you can wait that long- the different twist is, somehow, the bronx tale kid becomes suddenly fond of ablack girl and it's race relations; sure; deniro walking through another part, wife is good, mafia boos is good, plot is 75% steal

reviews.review_title: Probably means a lot to the locals and principles - mediocre to us outsiders.
reviews.content: A boy grows up in the 1950's Bronx and starts falling under the influence of the local Mafiosi and suchlike bad company. Robert De Niro's directorial debut.De Niro plays a dull, but moral, bus driver father rather than the obvious big bad boss. Why? Because he can, it is his show! One of the early walk through parts!So he learnt to drive a bus for this role - so what! So can Rowan Atkinson and a million other work-a-days. If he wanted to impress us why didn't he learn to play the clarinet for New York/New York rather than mime to someone else's work? Or at least learn that wind instruments have to be blown in to!Here - very late in life - he wants to be Mr Director. Why again? Because it is something he hadn't tried? Does he think he is better at it than others who have worked their way up through the ranks via pop videos, student films or commercials? (Am I being too harsh here - do you think that he is more than a dabbler?)Mafia men have money, girls and smart suits. They don't appear to work much and yet everybody bows-and-scrapes to them. Then they wrap their expensive cloth around the shoulders of our junior hero and say "hey, don't follow me, this isn't the life for you. Don't let me be your hero." Or words to that effect. (What is that expression - actions speak louder than words?)Because there really isn't a lot for the script to do we hang out with De Niro junior (played by two actors) and see his early sexual fumbles and listen to his stupid offencive racist mouth. The atmosphere is well created - but I am not sure what I am learning here? Stupid people do and say stupid things? Thanks for telling us!(While all this is happening The Mob is probably pummelling some bad debtor with a baseball bat - hey, Mr D. we're missing the real action!)Personally I am sick of wise-guys with their sharp suits bought by the sweat of others. Why are these guys "so special"? Why are they so often the centre of films? Well partly because they are interesting and provide easy drama (and easy violence) that you never have to explain.If they didn't crop up so often here this would be a dull coming of age picture.And far less people would pay to see it. Next to no one in fact.

In this film, there was a great story that I remember to this day. I will forget many movies about what they were for in a week, but I will have this movie in my head forever. Great course, selection director, great robert de niro. And most importantly, unforgettable voices with a great idea. I just love this movie.

A Bronx Tale is an biographical movie a bit different from all the classic mafia type ones in the sense that here, you're not an « insider » but you adopt an observing posture through Calogero, who is in fact Chazz Palmintieri, author of the play, the script and actor on the set as Sonny.He has depicted with sincerity and endearment his childhood and the world he grew up in, this Italian neighbourhood of Fordham in the Bronx, torn between the voice of reason, his father, an honest bus driver, and the easy life of Sonny's crew, his other paternal figure who took him under his wing but never associated him with his activities.The movie remains overall quite conventional in its approach and lacks grip to rise to the level of Goodfellas and others.

De Niro's directorial debut has given me so many life lesons. First of all.....never chase a guy down the street for $20...it just cost you that to understand you don't that person in your life. Secondly....it's never just about the Parking Space! 3rd you get 3 true loves in your life, if she reaches over to unlock your car door she's a keeper. 4th and maybe most importantly...is it better to be loved or feared??? All of these questions are asked and answered to a certain degree in one of Cinema's finest Actors Directorial Debut! De Niro as the unassuming Bus Driving father and Chazz Palminteri as the respected "family" man vying for the affections of a torn teenage boy (De Niro's son) another MUST see film that will impact your life.

This is a very strong movie. It has a convincing storyline and all the actors are simply wonderfully cast. Robert DeNiro's part is well-developed. The arising conflict with his son and the decent obligation he feels towards his son's moral alignment is both pervasive and very genuinely staged. I liked the dialogues as well as the development of the story, the subtle depiction of the setting (both time and location) and the very convincing character portrayal, as I said before. The story serves as a symbol for the moral tension and the reckless decisions people who live in a certain environment have to make in order to find their place in the world. Wonderfully transformed, a fine depiction of social circumstances and influences affecting individual convictions.
This is an excellent movie, De Niro is superb as is everyone else. You would have sworn it was a Scorsese movie, Thats how good it is. It's in my Top Ten.

Wow, this movie is just so very very good :-)
Its funny, exciting, romantic..... And funny :-D
The characters is hilarious, and you cant help to think that their way of life is okay.
Leave them be :-)

reviews.review_title: Delivers on all cylinders -- A truly great film!
reviews.content: To say the least I was surprised, deeply surprised with the quality of this film because I watched it, having never heard of it and it delivered on all cylinders for me. This is a truly great film, with people you care about. Robert De Niro, a very talented actor also happens to be a very talented director and every scene in this film plays out to a tee. The characters are likable from the get-go but most of all they're believable, the neighbourhood feels is close-nit, like family and that's what it's all about. What I found refreshing is that the story never plays into the hand of cliché's, keeping it all genuine and honest. This film isn't an epic, but that doesn't make it any less of a film, it's simply A Bronx Tale, and a moving one at that.

Overwhelming on every aspect!The story, the characters, the camera...
Brilliant performance of Chazz Palminteri, Lillo Brancato (especially in his youth), Robert De Niro and other great actors...
As a father of two children, the plot touches me very deeply...
Although almost 30 years past, the essence is eternal: from the childhood, to the teenage and to the adult; it's essential, that person must have all (healthy) liberty, to acknowledge his own way of life...
From my perspective, one, if not the best motion picture I have ever seen...
Hat down to all, that make this movie so great..
Nowadays, I miss such stories... TALES... 🤗😊

"A Bronx Tale" is a wonderful movie. I've seen it many times and I never get bored of watching it. I think the acting is great and the plot is also very clever."A Bronx Tale" tells the story of Calogero, who later becomes known as "C", growing up in the Bronx in the 1960s. He later befriends a mobster named Sonny, and they have an everlasting friendship. Calogero's father Lorenzo, is a bus driver, and he tries to prevent his son from becoming associated with the mafia.My favorite part of the movie is when Sonny tells Calogero that if Jane unlocks the car door for him, then she is the right girl for him. I also like the fight with the bikers in the bar.Overall this is a really good movie and I suggest everyone should see it. I give this movie 10/10 stars!

For the first 30 minutes I just sat cringing - every imaginable cliché about the mafia and Italians and the wonderful idyllic childhood this mix creates poured forth. You've heard it a hundred times before and, guess what, better. The head mafia guy in the district "was loved by everyone" (ahem, even though the hero's father despises him and we learn that very few people truly like him - the cliché therefore being contradicted by the rest of the film) and of course, everyone has their own cute nickname. The only original addition was that of race and racism, specifically, against African-Americans (but hey, guess what, the hero is DIFFERENT - he doesn't really share the prejudices of his friends). This too though was handled rather ham-fistedly, at one point a character uses a racist term and the next minute the person on the receiving end of it has not only forgotten it but forgiven it completely. It was a plot-serving cop-out of the highest order.Furthermore, for a film directed by such a consummate actor as De Niro, there are a few bad performances - specifically by the teenage version of the hero and his love interest (who was actually appalling).That said, by half way through I got a bit more drawn into the story, but this is still a very inferior mafia/growing up film.

Robert de Niros directorial debut is commendable. As you watch the film it is clear that many of the aspects are influenced from de Niros time with Martin Scorsese. However, saying this, it is because of the similarities that the differences stand out more.The story gravitates around the local mob boss, Sonny, and his relation with Calogero - yet very little of the story is focused on Sonnys criminal life - we only get a few glimpses into his backhand dealings - mostly illegal gambling. The real story is of how a good natured kid can be pushed and pulled between influences surrounding him during his formative years. And it unfolds into some Bronx-Gangster themed Romeo and Juliet story - sans the tragedy.For a film set in the Bronx and focused around gangsters, the real crime is the realisation that those closest to Calogero/"C" are the ones who know him the least, and hurt him the most. The antagonists are his own feelings towards his family and friends, and the constant moral and situational conflicts which threaten to drown C. Surprisingly it is the "bad guy" who is the most honest with C, and the one who listens and recognises who he actually is.His father, played by Robert de Niro, is a typical Italian-American male and a straight shooter, who tries above and beyond to protect his son from the street, yet attempts to impose both a sense of honour and masculine strength onto his son - which only results in their relationship being at arms length.There are a lot of life lessons in the film - acceptance, judgements, racism, how the good can be bad and vice versa, and the virtues of not following the crowd.There is a lot of cultural exposure in the show. The film opens with the line "This is the Fordham section of the Bronx... my home. A world unto itself. You can get to any borough in 15 minutes from here, but they might as well be 3,000 miles away" - and this is proven with the African-American borough practically next door which comes across as miles and worlds apart.Being a crime/gangster film, there is surprisingly a lack of violence and action - only about 5 or 6 sequences with such content. However this does not weaken the story, nor are any of the sequences executed tastelessly.Stand outs - Francis Capra acting as Calogero at age 9 - his acting is impeccable. He has such attitude, and such composure for such a youngster.Whilst this film is no Goodfellas, I find it has been overlooked and underrated - it is definitely worth a watch if you like New York crime dramas, in the vein of neighbourhood gangs.

And as Calogero grew up, he not only witnessed his boss ' other bloody deeds, but also found himself on the edge of a precipice. It's just a pity that at the end of the movie, he didn't stay, or marry her.

reviews.content: What an absolute masterpieceThe story is gripping and very smart with an amazing lesson at the end. Movie has a lot of heart. I love how they approach the racism back then in the movie. I can't believe how the actor who plays De Niro's son looks like him.Acting is on point from everybody maybe except Jane whose lines sometimes are rough on the edgesI'm just speechless what an absolute gem of a movie.

reviews.review_title: Coming of age in the Bronx.
reviews.content: An absolute treasure. Written by Chazz Palminteri and directed by Robert De Niro; both men star in this vivid glimpse of a young Italian-American boy named Calogero idolizing the neighborhood crime boss Sonny(Palminteri)from his apartment stoop. 'C's father Lorenzo is a hard working bus driver(De Niro)that only wants the best for his son. Sometimes the best bad guy make the bests good guy. 'C' witnesses Sonny killing a man and begins coming to grips with is it better to be loved or feared.The young boy is drawn to the power and respect that Sonny has and is actually taken under the wing of the small-time wise guy. By the age of 17 'C' will a proper education along with what he has learned on the streets. He finds himself being Sonny's shadow and his idol has treated him as his own. Lorenzo is hurt with his son's acquired notion that working men are suckers. 'C' will endure hard life lessons in the areas of love and death.A BRONX TALE is based on Palminteri's one-man play and is the directorial debut of De Niro. The younger Calogero is played by Francis Capra and the teenage 'C' is played by Lillo Brancato, who got the job by impersonating De Niro. Also in the cast: Taral Hicks, Clem Caserta, Eddie Montanaro, Alfred Sauchelli Jr. and Kathrine Narducci.Very good time period scenery, photography and props. One of my favorite scenes is when Sonny is driving the red convertible in reverse. The film makes great use of an exceptional soundtrack featuring the likes of: The Flamingos, The Cleftones, Dion & The Belmonts, Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin, James Brown, Huey P. Smith, Tony Bennett and Wilson Pickett.

I'd rank among the top 5 performances I ever watched as his performance of Sonny it was that good.Story revolves around Colegro or C and the two main male role models figures in his life. His hard working and honest bus driver father Lorenzo and the local neighborhood gangster Sonny. One day the young C witness a shoot out and murder in front of his stoop and his life is forever changed. Sonny takes C under his wing the rest of his life while Lorenzo objects.While Sonny is a gangster he's very smart and philosophical and protective of C. Almost like another father to him. Which causes tension between him and his old man.Great story along with great life lessons in this one.

I feel that Robert de Niro did a great job in directing this motion picture, this picture depicted the very essence of life in the Bronx during the 1960's, it shows the unbias character of a teenager and the love to a black girl, which might not of really happen in those days but could. Robert De Niro also did a superb job of acting in the movie.I will always remember this as one of the great pictures of all time.

Amazing mafia film, it's the first film directed by De Niro and he did a great job, the film written by Palminteri based on his childhood life, which make the film more realistic.If you like mafia movies, you have to watch this, but be informed that the film has more drama than action.

reviews.review_title: As far back as I can remember, I always wanted to be a director...
reviews.content: Sonny is the man in the Bronx neighbourhood of Italian boy Calogero. A shooting witnessed by the boy (nicknamed C by Sonny) is the starting point of a lasting bond between the gangster and the boy. His father Lorenzo disapproves. C grows up under the wing of both men, torn between his own natural honesty and his fascination with Sonny. C's neighbourhood friends get involved in theft, and racially fuelled fights. When C falls for an African American girl, things don't get any better.....It's quite admirable for an actor with such screen presence as De Niro to not only try and emulate Scorcese's arguably finest hour Goodfellas, but to take a back seat when it comes to letting people show their range.But as admirable emulating Goodfellas is, you cannot help but compare this film to that, and ultimately, finding many flaws with the film. Yes, the source material is based on Palminteri's theatre production, but there are so many similarities, right to a special guest appearance from an old friend in the last scene.But it's still a wonderful film, seeing Henry, sorry C grow up and create this subliminal partition from the real world, and the fantasy he is living when he is with Sonny.The racial tension is a pivotal point in the films narrative, and it's like a metaphorical melting pot that bubbles more and more and the film concentrates more on C, rather than the tension between Lorenzo and Sonny.Some of the scenes are beautifully crafted, especially the dice scene, which is as funny as it is sinister. De Niro keeps an air of tension in the film, but divides it with the family life, and the mobster life, and when the two interact with each other, the fight for the alpha male in C's life is up there with some of the most thrilling scenes seen in crime drama.For a debut, De Niro has crafted something that isn't just wonderfully authentic, but keeps the audience involved in all aspects of the story.it's a shame that it's sadly fallen under the radar since it's release, but it's worth seeking out for the similarities between this and Goodfellas.

Robert DeNiro stars and for the first time directs what was obviously a pet project, the growing up in the early 60's of a young Italian-American boy in the Bronx, New York. De Niro plays the father of what we see as initially a 9 year old kid, Colegiro, later shortened to C, a boy so fascinated and attracted to the power and attendant lifestyle of the neighbourhood Mr Big, the self-styled Tony, that he instinctively covers for him after the latter goes too far In ending a local feud. This linkage between proves life-changing, as, despite the workaday honesty of his bus-driver father setting a perfectly good example, it's the lure of charismatic Tony's Machiavellian lifestyle which has the bigger pull on the boy, posing him some big moral dilemmas later in life.Despite some extremely violent scenes, in particular when some troublesome "Hell's Angels" get run out of town and when a gang-feud between the Italians and the blacks reaches a literally explosive conclusion, at its heart, this movie has a soft, sentimental centre as young C, wouldn't you know it, falls West Side Story-style for a young black girl.Watching the movie. you get to thinking that growing upon the Bronx is a pretty full-on experience with probably just too much going on, stretching credibility about a bus-run too far, but nevertheless it's never less than entertaining, with some humorous inserts, like the naming of Tony's cronies at the start and the moment the gang's horse-racing hopes turn, literally, to mush, counterpointed by the struggle of the two father-figures for the soul of Coligero. DeNiro shows some neat directorial touches, especially the synchronised title sequence set to music and also gets fine performances from his young leads, adroitly underplaying his own part so as not to dominate proceedings.No doubt this film means more to Americans, especially New Yorkers of a certain extraction and age-group, but I was happy to suspend my disbelief at young C's rich and lurid boy-hood and was perfectly happy to tuck into this big bowl of Italian pasta, good to the last drop.

Robert De Niro's directorial debut 'A Bronx Tale' is an honest and well-told story, that has enough potential to earn itself a viewing. A hard-hitting human-drama, that is well-written, nicely directed and supremely acted.'A Bronx Tale' synopsis: A father becomes worried when a local gangster befriends his son in the Bronx in the 1960's. Living in the Bronx can be hard and Chazz Palminteri's Screenplay corrects that fact convincingly. Also, The characters look real, the dialogue are well-worded and the culmination to this story, is up-to the mark. De Niro's direction is under-stated, yet progressive. Cinematography, Editing & Art Design, are decent. Performance-Wise: De Niro owns the film. He is fantastic! Chazz Palminteri is first-rate. Lillo Brancato, Jr. does very well. Francis Capra leaves a lasting impression. Joe Pesci shows up in a tiny cameo towards the end of the film. Others are perfect. On the whole, A Well-Told Story, that is worth a watch. Thumbs Up!

The story may be a simple one but never less still very moving and well performed. But what gives this movie really the final touch to make it great is the soundtrack. Also the display of the old New York and how your cultural background somehow determines how your life will go was great executed.

reviews.review_title: "The saddest thing in life is a wasted talent" - but where's the proof of that?
reviews.content: I agree with all of the panegyrics, so I'll only point out the one thing that everyone seems to be missing (and it's not hard to do, given how mesmerizing the movie is) and which "ruined it" for me.One of the pivotal morals of the story, its leitmotif, is the now famous line "The saddest thing in life is a wasted talent". It appears at the beginning, throughout, and again at the end. It's practically the closing line.Yet we never see the MANIFESTATION of said talent in Calogero. What's he talented in? School? Baseball? Italian cuisine? We never get even the slightest indication of what that line might refer to when it comes to our protagonist.In my opinion, if such an important (if not THE most important) aspect of the movie had been "anchored" in something concrete (if we'd seen Calogero excel in baseball, school, whatever), the movie might have packed a stronger punch. Calogero leaves his mafia ways, having finally realized what his father has been talking about all along - that there's nothing sadder than a wasted talent.But we never see what Calogero's talent is!That's why the oft-repeated wasted-talent moral seems to be left hanging in mid-air without any concrete point of reference. It might as well have been replaced with "Take your vitamins daily". It's no more than an abstract wise saying. And that's why this movie hits the home run, but there's no bases on the field.Or something.

reviews.review_title: Stupid film unless I suppose you are Italian American
reviews.content: Despite a great cast I found this film to be poor. Despite being a murderer we are supposed to like the main gangster character 'Sonny'. His care of the protagonist, taking him under his wing and not wanting him to grow up like him, is frankly completely unbelievable. The character Sonny doesn't make any sense, on the one hand he is violent and treats people with disrespect, abusing his power, on the other he is kind but the two sides of his character are not shown in a way that would make sense. Also this film suffers from a really annoying narration from the protagonist - a sign in itself that the story is not well thought out and cannot make sense without this narration stitching it together. Robert De Niro doesn't appear that much and his role as the protagonist's father isn't really explored. Just about every plot turn doesn't really hold water. A romanticised silly film that I wouldn't watch again. I wouldn't bother if I were you.

This is a Godfather-type movie where an Italian boy named Calogero (Lillo Brancato) befriends a big-time gangster named Sonny (Chazz Palminteri) after Calogero witnesses a crime. Calogero's father Lorenzo (Robert De Niro) disapproves of the friendship, and things get a little murkier when Calogero falls in love with an African American girl named Jane (Taral Hicks) and his neighborhood becomes involved in theft, guns and racial tensions.The cinematography definitely gives this movie a fascinating film-noir atmosphere and some of the New York City scenes gives you the fast adrenaline of the big city feel and the uneasiness of its crime-infested streets. Coupled with the plot device of Calogero trying to choose his way of life within these streets gives the film some pretty nice action scenes and suspenseful moments, which is good for its sometimes slow plot. And, the subplot of the relationship between Calogero and Jane was pretty heartfelt, which does make up for the average acting. I don't watch much gangster films, but for this one being one of the few, it wasn't bad at all.Grade B-

The king of the Bronx mafia, Sonny, killed a man. Simply so. Because of the parking space. In broad daylight, he pulled out a pistol and fired several times. The police found out that the 9-year-old Calogero was a witness to the crime, and questioned the boy. But Calogero didn't give Sonny away. So their friendship began. And when Calogero grew up, he not only witnessed other bloody deeds of his boss, but also found himself on the edge of the abyss.

Excellent film directed by Robert de Niro and excellent acting by Robert de Niro, Chazz Paliminteri. The boy played by Lillo Brancato also acted very well. But there is only one drawback which is the use of strong language and violence to portray the life of American gangsters otherwise a good film. Overall a 9 out of 10.

A young boy, son to hard working bus driver De Niro does a local gangster (Palminteri) a big favour and is befriended for life much to his father's concern.Sweet, witty and occasionally violent, this is a touching coming of age drama with the boy learning good and bad things from both the gangster father figure and his own father. The cast are universally great fun and there is plenty to both think and titter about.Written by Parminteri and directed by De Niro, this is well worth catching up with.

There's a terrific song by the Moonglows called The Ten Commandments Of Love which is part of this movie's soundtrack, and which, for me, really captures what this story is about.It's a story about the friendship which develops between a young boy named Calogero Anello (Lilo Brancato), and local mob boss Sonny LoSpecchio (Chaz Palminteri) who owns the bar right next door to Calogero's tenement building.Set in the Bronx in the turbulent 1960's, it is also the story of the boy's father Lorenzo (Robert DeNiro), an honest, and hardworking man who's a bus driver for the city, and does not like his son getting mixed up with criminal elements.Thrown into the mix, and adding to the drama, is Calogero's attraction to a classy black girl named Jane Williams (Taral Hicks), at a time when racial tensions between blacks and whites was building to an explosion.The romance is like the cherry on the cake for me, it being so well done, so heartening, and inspiring (featuring a scene with another terrific song: I Only Have Eyes For You by The Flamingoes).Robert DeNiro does an incredible job directing this movie. It's a sparkling diamond of American film making.A great portrayal of love, loyalty, friendship, ties between father and son, and the seemingly trivial decisions that can alter our entire lives.Chaz Palminteri's script is perfect (in fact, I can't think of a single thing that could've been added or changed, it's really impressive).Joe Pesci also makes an appearance as Sonny's friend Carmine, and his presence (along with Lorenzo finally respecting Sonny), really makes the ending great.It should've won some Academy Awards. I can't believe it didn't. Rarely has there been such an excellent movie.

reviews.review_title: A Quality Movie with Mobster Flair
reviews.content: OK...yes, I confess. I am a mobster movie junkie and I also confess that I've seen this movie no less than 10 times....maybe more. That said, this is a superb coming of age tale about a young Italian kid that grows up in the Bronx, NY. He gets mentoring from two very different people . . . his straight shooter father, played by DeNiro and from the local mobster boss, played by Chazz Palmenteri. Both have the kids best interests at heart, but the way they mentor him is the whole plot of the story. There are several sub plots in this story. One plot was the complicated relationship of father and son; the relationship between an Italian mother and son; a young love story with a special twist in that its an interracial relationship in the turbulent racially tense 1960s; finally, the relationship between young friends growing up in the same neighborhood and all the mischief that results from their exploits. In a nutshell, A Bronx Tale make you smile and shed a tear - all the qualities of a quality drama. Enjoy this one - and enjoy the soundtrack, which is one of the best ever compiled! I don't know if the title of this film was familiar to me, but I noticed it was the debut by Robert De Niro as director, it sounded like a good plot and was rated well by critics, I was up for giving it a chance, and I'm glad I stuck with it. Basically in the Bronx, New York, nine year old Calogero Anello (Francis Capra) is the son of bus driver Lorenzo (Robert De Niro) and his wife Rosina (Kathrine Narducci), he has a fascination with the local mobsters of the neighbourhood, led by Sonny LoSpecchio (The Usual Suspects' Chazz Palminteri). One day Calogero witnesses Sonny murder someone, NYPD detectives question him and ask him to identify the killer from caught suspects, he chooses to keep quiet about Sonny, the mob leader takes a liking to the boy, giving him the nickname 'C', and introduced to the mob he makes money working in the Mafia bar and throwing dice, Lorenzo tells Sonny to stay away from his son, but Calogero ignores his father's words. Eight years pass, and Calogero (Lillo Brancato) is now a young man and still seeing Sonny on a regular basis, and despite the tension between the African American and Italian communities, particularly among his friends, he meets and is smitten with African American girl Jane Williams (Taral Hicks), and after getting to know her he arranges a date with her, he asks for advice from both Sonny and his father. The same night Calogero's friends beat up a group of black cyclists, he is powerless to stop them but tries to defend black young man Willy (Sobe Bailey), Jane's brother, so when Jane and he are meant to meet for their date she has brought her brother with her, he accuses Calogero of being one of the assailants, in the argument Calogero uses a racist cuss, the two siblings walk away upset. Lorenzo confronts his son about still seeing Sonny, and after leaving an argument Sonny himself confronts the young man, accusing him of putting a bomb on his car and attempting to assassinate him, Calogero pleads emotionally his innocence, the mob leader accepts this, Lorenzo also gets involved turning up during this, but he is held by the mobsters. Calogero catches up with Jane, she tells him that Willie has admitted he knows he wasn't one of those who beat him up, they make amends, but he remembers the plan by his friends to assault the African American community, they rush to stop it, but by the time they get there they are already dead, one of the thrown lit liquor bottles was thrown back and blew up their car. Calogero goes to Sonny to thank him for his help, but the son of the person he murdered eight year ago shoots the gangster in the back of the head, a funeral is held and those who knew him pay their respects, one man named Carmine (Joe Pesci) turns up as well, the young man recognises him from the shooting incident eight years ago. Surprisingly Lorenzo also turns up, he understands his son cared for Sonny, but he also comes to pay his own respects and thank him for saving the life of his son, he never hated Sonny, just resented him for making Calogero grow up so quickly, the father and son make peace, Calogero has learnt life lessons from his experiences with both men. Also starring Clem Caserta as Jimmy Whispers, Alfred Sauchelli Jr. as Bobby Bars, Frank Pietrangolare as Danny Ko, Robert D'Andrea as Tony Toupee and Eddie Montanaro as Eddie Mush. De Niro is well regarded for gangster movies, so he does very well both directing and playing the father of the leading young man, Brancato is a great choice to play the confused teenager stuck between two sides, Capra is also great as the child version of the character, and of course Palminteri is terrific as the mob boss. The story is based on both Palminteri's autobiographical experiences and his play, you can tell De Niro has his input in this film as it seems very much like GoodFellas, there is not much sentimentality and lots of hard hitting material to savour up, it works really well as both a character study and an intelligent portrayal of how bad influence can mess with morals, a great crime drama. Very good!

reviews.review_title: A Bronx Tale, One of the Best Movies of the 1990s
reviews.content: Chazz Palminteri wrote the play. Then, he wrote this script and actor Robert De Niro directed it. They both star in this movie about a boy growing up in the Bronx in the 50s and 60s. De Niro plays his dad, and Chazz is a hood, who is feared by all in his community, and who serves an influence to the boy. I really can't tell you how much I love this movie. De Niro and Chazz's love of the period are obvious to the viewer in the details, and the acting of these pros and the two young actors playing 'C' are incredible. While we see De Niro try to instill good values and morals into his son, a lot of the movie's goodness is there for the viewer to see rather than being told. The boy is exposed to the criminal element, because of a bar two doors down, which he is inevitably drawn to, despite his mother's orders to stay away from it, and because these "hoods" hang out all around him. He is exposed to his friends' prejudice against the blacks, but he realizes he has to think for himself and live by his own conscious. Along with the serious tones of the movie is its sense of humor, with Chazz sending people to the bathroom, because he's trying to concentrate on playing dice. And, of course, the soundtrack helps to set the mood, but it's only secondary to the film's heart, which is perfectly embodied in the young boy looking for himself and love and acceptance, in a world that could be overturned anytime, in this Bronx tale.

Not too be taken seriously, "A Bronx Tale" will be a worthwhile watch for those into wise guy flicks with some heart. (B)

reviews.review_title: De Niro should direct again -- this is a very well made movie.
reviews.content: Robert De Niro's "A Bronx Tale" is the story of a hard-working Italian-American man whose teenaged son takes an ill-advised interest in the neighborly Mafia figures. De Niro plays Lorenzo, a bus driver from the Bronx who works hard for a living and is perfectly content with his low amount of income, if only because it is clean. When he is offered a small Mafia job, he turns it down. The local Mafia kingpin is Sonny (Chazz Palminteri). "As I grew in age, he grew in power," says young Calogero, a.k.a. C, a.k.a. Lorenzo's son. In the beginning of the film, nine-year-old C witnesses a murder at the hands of Sonny, but doesn't rat on the man. Soon he is taken under the wing of the gangster, being thrust into the middle of gambling rackets and running errands of sorts. Lorenzo despises the Mafia and pleads with Sonny to leave his son alone. "They didn't speak ever again," says C, now seventeen years old (played by Lillo Brancato) and narrating the story. In a way, C suddenly has two fathers -- Lorenzo, who gives him good advice; and Sonny, whose advice is often times witty but not always the right thing. C is a confused kid, unsure of what to do with his life, hanging out with the wrong crowds. De Niro's performance as Lorenzo is the most touching in the film, because it is so true, and he displays the same caring side of all parents who want to give their kids good advice.One of the movie's only flaws is the stereotypical love interest subplot, this time between C and a sixteen-year-old black girl who goes to his school. C is the only kid on his block who doesn't want to take part in racist beatings and he is apparently the only one, at the time, who isn't bothered with the blacks' presence on the street. What is so disappointing about this rather unnecessary addition to the plot is that it feels tacky, one of the only unrealistic moments in an otherwise grandiose motion picture. C steps over the boundaries of being a respectable character, brought up by a very wise father, to a downright stereotypical Good Guy, who appreciates the minority figures and is the lone voice in a large crowd of haters. I'm not saying that C shouldn't fall in love with a black girl, but the entire subplot is entirely out of place, unnecessary, unbelievable (there is absolutely no chemistry between the two actors) and, to be blunt, silly. Silly, and a major error on De Niro's part, because it tries to manipulate its audience and turn C into an unrealistic, open-minded guy -- the sort of character who would have never existed back then, especially under the influence he grew up in.Oh well. The movie is still brilliant, almost perfect, aside from that superfluous subplot.The film was written by Palminteri, based on his own one-man play from 1989. As Sonny, Palminteri proves that he can exhibit the same sort of oozing confidence that De Niro displayed as Jimmy in Martin Scorsese's "Goodfellas," the best mob movie ever made, which bears a few resemblances to "A Bronx Tale." De Niro claims that in order to separate his film from others that have already dealt with the same sort of backdrop, he studied his own movies -- particularly those directed by Scorsese -- and tried to stray away from many techniques and ideas used in those movies. What De Niro delivers is an occasionally funny, occasionally painful, coming-of-age drama with guts. De Niro is right: these sorts of films have been made before, but in his directorial debut, De Niro proves that he isn't just one of the greatest actors of all time, but a gifted director with a stunning vision. De Niro's love and respect for New York City shines through in "A Bronx Tale," just about as much as his very obvious attention to detail and characters. This is one of the best Mafia movies ever made, even if it's towards the bottom of the list.4.5/5 stars.

reviews.content: I was very interested in seeing Robert De Niro's first directorial effort A Bronx Tale so when like a month or so ago I found its R4 DVD without not even looking for it I was very pleased. For this and that I just saw A Bronx Tale last night and while it was entertaining, good in parts it is mostly a disappointment for me even that I wasn't expecting to see a film as brilliant as Scorsese's Goodfellas. Well, De Niro has also an acting part (as in his second directorial effort The Good Shepherd that was released 13 years after A Bronx Tale and that have still to see) and is a good performance by De Niro as Lorenzo, the father of the main character Calogero. However this film hasn't terrific acting everywhere, to begin with the kid that plays Calogero age 9 (Francis Capra) yet this the first part of the film is the one that I liked the most, with a good De Niro, funny parts, is just very entertaining. A Bronx Tale has two parts, first part is in 1960 and is a pretty simple set: on one hand Calogero has in his father a real example, a working man devoted to his family and on the other hand has in the gangster Sonny (Chazz Palminteri is good, he also wrote the film) the man who is nothing but his idol, the man he really admires, the man who has never look at him, the man who everybody fears. The main thing in the second part of the film, that begins when we jump to 1968, is a racial issue: C's (Sonny renamed Calogero as C) all time friends have problems each time black men pass through "their" neighborhood. C on the other hand has no problem and he likes a black girl, is all really conventional, predictable, you know. Here we have Francis Capra, Lillo Brancato Jr. (who plays C during the second part of the film so who is Calogero age 17) and Taral Hicks (who plays C's love interest Jane Williams) doing their screen debut, none of these 3 did were good choices, the main character itself is very weak and very unlikable but mostly the problem is Taral Hicks, each time she was on the screen I was thinking, and also laughing a little, "why De Niro didn't found better actors?", she is really terrible. So A Bronx Tale was mostly a disappointment, still it has really great music: Hendrix (his brilliant version of Dylan's "All Along the Watchtower"), The Beatles (one of my favourites from them, "Come Together"), Cream, The Kinks, "Nights in White Satin" by The Moody Blues.

reviews.review_title: Good acting, good sketch, could have been done a little better
reviews.content: "A Bronx Tale" is a truly good movie. Though C (the characters name in the movie is called C) could be played better, Robert DeNiro and Chazz Palmentieri were great as always.The movie starts with Calegro Anello (or C, as he likes to be called) as a young boy (Francis Capra), growing up in Bronx in the midst of the mafia. His father Lorenzo (Robert De Niro) tries his best to give C what he wants, but he has never really been able to since he has an honest living as a bus driver. C has always looked up to local organized crime head Sonny (Chazz Palmentieri) more than anyone else, and tries to imitate him, but Sonny has not even met C yet. Then one fateful day, in a fight over what appears to be merely a parking space, Sonny decides to help out his friend (Joe Pesci in an amusing cameo) and shoots his assailant. C saw the whole thing, and the cops know C saw the whole thing. So they give C the opportunity to point out the gunman. C is put up in front of a lineup of "the usual suspects" but does not point the finger at any of them. Sonny is touched by this, and takes a minute to talk to C. He then offers Lorenzo the opportunity to deliver deals for Sonny in exchange for about 3 times the salary of what he makes now. He refuses, bent on making his living decently.  Sonny begins to let C around at his bar, making him the boy people call on when they want a beer or something. A relationship grows between the 2, but when Lorenzo finds out about the bar, and the money C is making at the bar, he refuses the money and makes C give it back. Later, you see C as a 17 year old (Lillo Brancato). Then even more tension begins as C struggles definitely to find his place in the Bronx. He's not sure if he wants to hang out with his bunch of racist friends, or work at the bar with the Sonny and the gang. Then he meets Jane (Taral Hicks) and things really get interesting. This is because Jane is black, and C is falling for her anyway....... > This movie is great, but a poor performance from Lillo Brancato and a little too much ground covered in the movie prevents it from being a classic. However, this movie is definitely worth watching for its perspective on racism, first love, and organized crime. Chazz Palminteri is positively oscarworthy and De Niro gives one of his best performances of the 90's.

The addition of the racial aspect brings something more to the gangster film genre. So much of this is amazing.

Robert DeNiro made his directorial debut with the gripping "A Bronx Tale", about a boy in 1960s New York torn between his father and a gangster. Bus driver Lorenzo Anello (DeNiro) raises his son Calogero to be an honest person, but Calogero also is interested in mobster Sonny (Chazz Palminteri, who based the story partly on his own childhood). What's really good about the movie is how it presents all sides of the dichotomy. For example, when Calogero claims that people respect Sonny, Lorenzo tells Calogero: "People respect me. They fear him." Everything in this movie is likely to shock you. You want Calogero to do what he wants, but you're nervous about hoping for him to go into a life of crime. If Robert DeNiro is to be best known for these kinds of roles, then so be it; he does them very well. The rest of the cast is also great. You may never feel the same after viewing this. Joe Pesci also appears.

In recent times, it seems as though that the chief talking point surrounding A Bronx Tale remains focused on the actor Lillo Brancato's descent into drugs and crime which reached a peak when he was arrested on suspicion of murdering a police officer. A stupid waste it may be, but it'd be a shame if it overshadows the movie itself, as Robert De Niro's first stint as director provided the world with an excellent film, worthy of standing shoulder to shoulder with any of the big players in the gangster movie genre.The movie tells the story of Calogero, a young Italian boy raised in the New York Bronx who has two very different father figures watching out for him. One is his birth father (De Niro), a low paid bus driver who doesn't want his only son to become involved in the wave of crime tainting the neighbourhood. The other is the local Mafia Kingpin Sonny (Chazz Palmintieri), who develops a bond with the boy when he refuses to rat on him following a murder in the street. As he grows up, he finds himself torn between these two distinct heroes who keep finding themselves at loggerheads, while violence in the neighbourhood threatens all of them.As the film plays out, the story becomes all the more riveting. De Niro is a triumph as always, but it is Palmintieri who really shines here. Sonny is perhaps the most human mafia Don the movies ever saw and his friendship with Calogero is really quite touching, despite the rift it creates with his birth father. But when all is said and done, Sonny has nothing but his best interests at heart, repeatedly encouraging him not to go down the same road he has and trying to steer him away from his rather deranged friends who seem fixated on becoming involved in crime.Whatsmore, the image of the Bronx we get is incredibly eye-catching, striking out like an urban wasteland of violence and dog-eat-dog ethics. Racial tensions between the minority groups manifest themselves in the street fights between Italian and African gangs, while a bar room brawl between the mafia and a bike gang early on leaves us in no doubt as to the hostile nature their world encapsulates.With the stereotypical depictions of many of the Mafia members (overweight Italians in vests with slick black hair engaging in 'business deals') remaining in place, A Bronx Tale covers familiar territory, but with the engrossing three way relationship between C and his two fathers, it also covers new ground. It breathes new life into the gangster genre and the end is nothing less than satisfying.

reviews.review_title: Honest film tugs at your heartstrings
reviews.content: The first thing A Bronx Tale should be commended for is getting a stellar performance out of what at the time was an inexperienced cast. Aside from Robert DeNiro (and a cameo by Joe Pesci), most of the players were novices, with several in their film debuts. But DeNiro managed to get A+ performances from Lillo Brancato Jr., Francis Capra and Taral Hicks. I thought Chazz Palminteri should have garnered an Oscar for his role. The fact that this was his screenplay, it was evident that he poured his heart into the role, and he was thoroughly believable as the neighborhood boss Sonny. Nuances are very important in a film, and DeNiro manages to capture the turbulent 60s perfectly. One particular scene is especially memorable. In the first conversation between the teenage Colagero and Jane -- when he's walking her home from school -- I'm not sure if the actors were allowed to ad-lib, but the dialogue was perfect, because it epitomized the awkward interaction of young love. Aside from that, the movie is honest about gangster life, racism and loyalty. The movie isn't preachy, and it doesn't have the feel-good ending of an afterschool special. What it does is show that even the worse people have good in them and that our choices are what ultimately decide our fate. A film with very few flaws.

A BRONX TALE (1993) ***1/2 Robert De Niro, Chazz Palminteri, Lillo Brancato, Francis Capra, Joe Pesci (cameo). I had actually seen this film about 10 years ago, but my husband's memory is faulty and he insisted we hadn't seen it, so I watched it again.I've learned a lot in 10 years and while my initial review might have been a 4 or 5, there is no other number for this but 1.The majority of this movie is basically dictated to us via voiceover from the teenaged Calogero, better known as "C" -- because that is apparently the only nickname that mob boss/street corner king "Sonny" (Chazz Palminteri) could come up with."C" (as performed by the handsome but minimally talented Lillo Brancato) takes us through his childhood and teenage years, observing everything with a none-too-bright point of view. We are hand-led throughout the "tale," and if there's a moment that Chazz (the writer and the star) thought that the audience might not understand, it is stated in clear, on-the-nose dialogue.There are multiple stories contained within this film, but the only one that actually held my interest for a moment was the budding love affair between "C" and the plain-named "Jane" (Taral Hicks), who, in the parlance of the day, was known as "a colored girl."Because "C" is tight with his childhood buddies, who have all turned into obnoxious, racist young thugs who somehow think that "hanging out" on the street and yammering about pointless things is the height of living, "C" must keep his interest in Jane a secret."C" is also enamored of Sonny, who takes interest in him as a child because "C" (as "Calogero," performed by Francis Capra, a boy with beautiful eyes and eyelashes, but not much talent) witnessed Sonny murdering a man in cold blood in daylight, but because he is a product of his neighborhood, he doesn't rat Sonny out. This makes Sonny, who is the Lord and Savior of his tiny bit of turf in the Bronx, think highly of Calogero, and thus begins the story of their father-son relationship... despite the fact that Robert De Niro (as "Lorenzo," a bus driver with a thimble full of morals more than Sonny) is Calogero's father.You see how convoluted and complicated and endless this all this? That's how it came across on the screen. The story did not really know what it wanted to focus on: Sonny and C's faux dad-son relationship; Sonny's complete power over his 'hood; Sonny's band of misfit henchmen who worship the ground he walks on; Lorenzo's attempts to raise a good son, despite the negative influences he's constantly surrounded by; the burgeoning romance between "C" and "Jane"; the deadly realities of what happens when the black folk move too close to the Italian neighborhood; the pointless lives of the young thugs that emulate Sonny and his goons, and to whom "C" feels beholden...It goes on and on. This might make sense as a limited series, if it can find its center, which this film never does. Also, it relies heavily on voiceover, which, at the time, must have been thought to be really elegant and the proper way to tell a story, but in 2022, it comes across as artifice and annoys within the first two minutes.The movie does do a good job of recreating the era, or it seems to. And it is also a sad comment on people's inability to accept others that are different from them.The ending, also dominated by a voiceover, lets us know how much "C" has learned and what's important in life, even though he never ever seemed to learn anything or show any maturity. He also held on to his lack of critical thinking and rage almost to the end, neither of which served him well.Overall, except for a few brief moments with "Jane," who is sunny and sweet and seems to have some sense and intelligence, everyone else in this movie seems locked into incredibly limited views of themselves. As such, there is no one to root for or care about (except maybe Jane, but even she returns to "C" after he cruelly insults her and his brother, so, I'm thinking she didn't think things through, either).One fun tidbit: There's a moment where Calogero's mother "Rosina" (played by Kathrine Narducci) says something like, "I have to go check on the baby." -- We never see a baby, nor do we see any other child as "C" grows up. Nor, in fact, do we see "Rosina" once "C" becomes a teen.This story is heavy on angry, racist, small-minded men who think they are kings of their turf and have no idea of what life has to offer, since they think the world is their corner.Perhaps the best thing about the movie was the soundtrack, which featured many hits of the day.Otherwise, unless you long to hear people speaking in a Bronx accent for over two hours, enjoy lots of violence, and don't mind being led by the nose through plot points, you are missing nothing.

reviews.review_title: A parable on values and an appreciation for life
reviews.content: A Bronx Tale successfully brings out every emotion your system can handle. From anger, to joy, to laughter, to happiness, to sympathy, to empathy, to tears, and to, finally, satisfaction as the final scene fades into credits. This is De Niro's directorial debut and he handles the challenge exquisitely. Complimented by Chazz Palminteri's slick and fearless writing that documents the struggles, the gangs, and the racism of the Bronx streets with no sugarcoating and no easy ways out.Adapted from its stage play counterpart, A Bronx Tale focuses on the famous area in New York where little nine year old Calogero (played by Francis Capra during his tender years) is growing up on the unapologetic streets with his bus driver father Lorenzo (De Niro) and his nervous mother. Lorenzo frequently warns Calogero that "the saddest thing in life is a wasted talent," hoping that his son will take the path of untold success later in life.One day, while sitting idly on his stoop with his buddies, Calogero witnesses a murder. The murder was made by the area mafia boss Sonny (Palminteri). Him and his crew are respected, at the same time feared for their unpredictable actions and their checkered history. When called back to the scene by detectives looking for the murderer, young Calogero lies and refuses to confess. His father is subtly proud, but warns his son that he has just done a good thing for a bad person. The good news is their family won't be on the hit list. The bad news is their family is now on the suspicious list.Eight years later, Calogero, now played by Lillo Brancato Jr., is nicknamed "C" by Sonny and has become his main-man. His second son as well as his partner in crime. His father is somewhat oblivious to what his son has been up to recently, but he believes he can take care of himself, while still nudging him in the right direction.Sonny's philosophy is greatly different from Lorenzo's. It's "nobody really cares." When the chips are down, who's there to care? Nobody. You're a worthless human. The brutally honest, shameless half of the glass. Sonny's philosophy sticks with Calogero, but he also keeps his father's in mind. Do the two connect? Maybe in some ambiguous, unorthodox way, but it just seems they are two contradicting ways of life. Here's a film that also shows us that if we're lucky, we get two different outlooks on life from two very different people. A man who works in a town and a man who owns it.De Niro was in a very rough position when it came time to grab a hold of the camera for this film. He could either take the easy way out and make a Goodfellas-style mobster flick or mimic his stellar character's lifestyle in Raging Bull. But he doesn't. He most likely was the go-to guy for help with the script and offered Palminteri advice, but in no way is this another mafia film. It's a unique kind of mafia film. It shows the long-lasting and life changing effects it has on a youth growing up on the wrong side of the streets.This greatly reminds me of a phenomenal film from the eighties that tackles the same sort of subject. The film was John Singleton's Boyz N The Hood, setting its sights on three troubled youths growing up in the hood and getting caught in the mix of crime, drugs, and racism. The film was Singleton's directorial debut as well, featured stellar performances from every actor in it, a genius script, and some fantastic honesty about the life of the hood. A Bronx Tale does the same, but centers its story around the mafia. Not glorifying the violence, not acting pretentious over other classics of the same genre, but taking a cliché and turning it into a gritty reality.What is important to learn from A Bronx Tale is that it's a movie with values. It believes that beliefs and values should be the first thing someone should consider when in a serious situation. Sometimes we don't think about the consequences and dive right into what we think will satisfy ourselves and turn out the way we want in no time. It too forms the question; is it better to be universally loved or feared? I'd rather be a little bit of both with a strong blend of respect.Starring: Lillo Brancato, Jr., Chazz Palminteri, Robert De Niro, Taral Hicks, Francis Capra, Kathrine Narducci, Clem Caserta, and Joe Pesci. Directed by: Robert De Niro.

"It don't take much strength to pull a trigger. But try and get up every morning day after day, and work for a living. Let's see him try that. Then we'll see who the real tough is. The working man's the tough guy. Your father's the tough guy" Lorenzo Anello (Robert De Niro) to his son Calogero (Francis Capra) Never truer words of wisdom have ever been spoken in a gangster film since "The Godfather" and through a simple yet powerful speech, De Niro defines what I humbly call the 'anti-gangster' genre.Most classic gangster films tackled the theme of Family in a way or another, as to underline the ambivalent nature of men, capable of the worst actions in the name of the noblest virtues, if not for pure survival instinct. This applies to "The Godfather", but also other classics such as "Bonnie and Clyde", "Road to Perdition" and even the pre-Hayes gangster flicks that featured gangsters as more than simple cold-blooded killers: Tony Camonte in "Scarface" (and his 1983 alter-ego Montana) had an oedipal devotion to his sister, Tom Powers in "The Public Enemy" envied his honest brother and the same James Cagney was an unforgettable mama's boy in "White Heat".The family element is less an alibi than a plot element inviting us to understand what kind of motives lies behind the cruelest acts: when organized crime becomes a matter of territory and survival, it necessarily inspires the most bestial instincts, and nourishes the feeling of belonging to the same blood. Family is important enough for honest people, but for those who are in a constant mortal danger, it's not just a sacred value, it's the only one that can prevail, and keep a level of humanity and dignity to rather despicable characters. I apologize for the length of this introduction, but sometimes the genius of a film is to make us question our most intimate convictions. All I mentioned is precisely the reason why I love gangster films, they often happen to be 'more than that' because of the intricate interaction between Crime and Family (sometimes, similar themes like friendships in "Once Upon a Time in America") and Robert De Niro's Bronx Tale made me questions my own appreciation of gangster flicks in a way that even Scorsese didn't.The speech Robert De Niro gives to his little boy about the working man being the tough guy, is the emotional core of the film. The 8-year old Calogero aka 'C', after witnessing the local mob boss Sonny (Chazz Palminteri) killing a man, took the wise decision not to identify him when questioned by the police, therefore starting a father-and-son bonding that enriched his education with stuff that would have never been taught by his father, a modest bus driver. Yes, Sonny IS a gangster, but he owns the Bronx, he's respected, feared and somewhat loved, exuding a charisma that inspires all these relatively compatible feelings. Tutoring 'C', Sonny progressively becomes the counterpart of Lorenzo's education, and the first act of the film features a small 'C' in the same position than Henry Hill in the beginning of "Goodfellas" with a slower pacing and a great dosage of drama and humor. We smile at young 'C' tutored by the bad-ass Sonny, until the film really takes the beautiful dimension of an existential conflict.The conflict is perfectly illustrated in the poster, where both De Niro and Palminteri face each other and 'C' is like taken hostage of two visions of life that would "shape his life forever" but each one, differently. I mentioned "Goodfellas" because although it has a superior quality, "A Bronx Tale" strikes by its thought-provoking story: we're seduced by the gangster lifestyle but also witness the way it's endured by the parents. It's just as if "Goodfellas" focused on Mr. Hill's character. But while Scorsese was only teasing us until the end where we could realize how foolish we were to root for scumbags, De Niro doesn't copy his directorial model (I allow myself this assumption since the movie has a strong Scorsesian feel), and never falls in the patronizing trap of blind denunciation, it's never Lorenzo vs. Sonny, good vs. bad guys, but about young 17-year old 'C' (Lillo Brancato) who tries to take the best from each one. Of course at the beginning, he's rooting for Sonny, but he genuinely loves and respects his father, and at the end, he knows he learned from both.When 'C' asks Sonny: "Is it better to be loved or feared?" Sonny replies that it's nice but difficult: "If i had a choice I'd rather be feared, fear last longer then love. Friendships bought with money mean nothing" This moment echoes the reading of some pages from Machiavelli's "Prince", a book Sonny admitted to have read in prison. The character of Sonny can indeed be described as Machiavellian, always justifying his actions by a sort of cold pragmatism. On the other hand, Lorenzo is more of a practical man, who takes life as it is, and takes his role as a father very seriously. He loves to have fun with his boy at the baseball game, he tells him to finish his steak, he provides some advices about sex and love, and he's the average guy, tender and tough enough to inspire our respect and our admiration.De Niro wonderfully balances between two educations with enough courage to show how crime can really waste a life, and enough detachment to prove that one doesn't need to be criminal to spend his whole life wasting his talent, which is even worse. Crime is certainly not glorified but not simplistically condemned either, hence my epithet of "anti-gangster", I could have said revisionist but although the ending seems to lean over the honest vision, "A Bronx Tale" less tries to teach us lessons but to show us that the greatest lessons take sometimes the most unlikely media to be taught.

A BRONX TALE opens with a long continual view of a street in the Bronx, stopping at an entrance way to a modest looking multi-use building with apartments on the second and higher level floors.  As this takes place, a voice-over tells the viewer, "...and this is my stoop, 667 [something] Street..." and sure enough, there is a nice dark green awning with easy to read "667" by the stairs.However, the awning belongs to the first floor market, not to the apartments above.  "667" is really the address of the market.  The entrance way steps and door used to access the apartments above would be either 665 or 669, depending upon which direction the numbers ran.   So, the address where the Bronx tale unfolds is fudged as the producers confidently assume that dummy viewers would never know how street addresses of multi-use buildings work.There are many Hollywood movie making simplifications in play here.  For example, the dramatic, but unreal, police line-up early in the film would not be done as it was, even if it was done in Mayberry, NC, and Deputy Sheriff Fife was in charge!If one is a big fan of voice-overs, this movie is for you.  If not, give A BRONX TALE a pass.

reviews.review_title: A story you can revisit over and over again
reviews.content: It is a good film about the Bronx, about Little Italy in New York, race relations in the 60s and many other things, indeed. Yet the film seems to be a country revisited several times. The new element is the point of view that is adopted here, that of a kid who is growing from 8 to 17 and is the witness of the law of the neighborhood and how this law is imposed by some group of self appointed people who impose security and guarantee it then. In this case it is an Italian boss, and on the other side it is the Blacks, and no detail is given. What makes this film interesting is how the son sees the world and how he comes to accepting this or that idea, from his father or the local neighborhood boss. We see his personality growing, his independence blooming, at times without knowing it, his reason and moderation expanding at times against his own feelings and convictions. You add girls to that and then accidents on the road of social peace and you may have some real drama in which you discover the real value of this man, or even your father, who did not hate this or that or anyone in particular but rather tried, at times awkwardly to protect you. There are a few funny elements here and there, more dramatic elements now and then, but a lot of pathos all the time. Entertaining with good actors who are very well directed.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU, University Paris Dauphine, University Paris 1 Pantheon Sorbonne & University Versailles Saint Quentin en Yvelines

A Bronx Tale is a superb film covering a whole host of genres with very impressive acting performances and interesting use of music/song. Robert De Niro has directed very well and has done his usual, flawless best with the few scenes he was acting in. Palminteri on the other hand, has a much larger role which he delivers with the usual grit and aggression you'd expect with him when he's involved in crime films (I'm thinking 'The Usual Suspects' and 'Running Scared'). What's also rather special is that Palminteri wrote it.The film very much feels like a play in a strange sort of way. The use of diegetic music within the films universe is present and each song is spot on with the scene it's overlapping. From Huey Smith and the Clowns' 'Don't You Just Know It' which is obviously a very chirpy, bouncy, cheeky song which is playing over kids messing around with a fruit truck to the mellow 'I Only Have Eyes For You' which introduces itself at various stages during the protagonist's gaze at a girl from a rival gang in the neighborhood. Each track works very well and it does feel at times, like it's some sort of Broadway, gangland musical which makes everything feel much more unique.What makes this film a little bit more special is that its 'Goodfellas-esque' approach in telling the story of one boy whom becomes one man allows us to map on more to the character and his surroundings and his relationships which build up and fall down over the period of time with others, namely his childhood friends, his father played by De Niro and his 'second father'/boss played by Palminteri. The lack of De Niro on screen actually adds to the atmosphere in a rather odd way. We are seeing him or 'noticing him' about as much as the protagonist is and that's only every now and again; nothing special, whereas Palminteri's character is very much the focal point for, not only business, but also pleasure and socialising.I think 'A Bronx Tale' has snuck into my top ten favorite crime films as it feels gritty and unique and that's what does it for me; the atmosphere and real feel of a crime film. The simplistic street setting, the chain of cause and effect plot points which move onto one another at just the right moments, the crafty use of diegetic music all combining nicely at various intervals to create something truly moving. There is something in this film for everyone: the music, the tragedy, the romantic element, the action/crime theme- everything. I'd recommend it.

A Bronx Tale, as the title indicates, takes place in that famous New York City borough, home of the Yankees. It is the 1960s and Lorenzo(Robert De Niro) drives a bus and tries to set a good example for his son Calogero(Francis Capra). The boy witnesses a murder by a local mob boss, Sonny(Chazz Palminteri) but keeps quiet, earning the killers respect. Lorenzo is offered a job in the underworld but turns it down, preferring to remain honest. His son, however, secretly works for Sonny running errands. As he grows older, Calogero hangs out with a gang comprised of fellow Italian teenagers up to mischief. His father talks him out of his bad habits and Calogero meets a black girl, Jane and begins a relationship with her causing much animosity with his white friends. A small race riot occurs within the love and crime story. De Niro has done a marvelous directing job with Palminteri's very personal and heart felt storyMore complications arise with Sonny and the crime world, as always, has violent consequences for those choosing that colorful lifestyle.
