reviews.review_title: Solid mob film that really pulls at the 'heart strings'
reviews.content: I really enjoyed 'A Bronx Tale' and found it to be a wonderful film that tears your emotions to shreds.We begin in 1960 with Lorenzo Anello (De Niro) and his son Calogero and his wife Rosina who are all living in the Bronx. Lorenzo is a bus driver who earns a fairly pitiful wage. Lorenzo is a hard working man who does everything he can to provide for his family (including working 7 days a week). He is aware of some of the 'questionable' activities which occur in his neighbourhood, but prefers to keep his head down and not get involved. He also tries to keep his son out of trouble by telling him to 'sit on the step' outside their house and not to go near the bar (due to the Mob hanging out there). However, when Lorenzo's son witnesses lead Mob member Sonny (Chazz Palminteri)killing someone outside his home and then deliberately fails to pick him out of a police line up, Sonny and his crew develop respect for Calogero and decide to take him under their wing; One major aspect of film enjoyment is the ability to buy into the premise and for me this is where A Bronx Tale works. It is loosely based on Palminteri's experiences as a child so it isn't entirely fictional. Calogero (or C as he becomes known as later) is attracted by the mob way of life; him and his friends are constantly imitating Sonny and his crew. He likes the idea that they drive round in nice cars and that everyone fears them - it's believable, kids are impressionable so I could buy into the fact that Calogero would want a piece of the action. This becomes even more evident when Calogero makes an easy $600 dollars at the tender age of 9 when he started working for Sonny.Another aspect that I liked about this film is the characters and the depth that they are afforded; I felt sympathy for Lorenzo. There were many occasions where Lorenzo felt that he was losing his son to Sonny - Calogero was attracted to the mob way of life - the money, the cars, the power, the fear. How can he compete on the measly wage that he earns? Lorenzo can't offer his son the things that Sonny can offer him. This made me care for his character and whilst I don't have kids myself, I could empathise with his character and I can understand that he will do everything he can to protect his son. Even Sonny becomes some what likable towards the end - again all the characters are given 'human qualities'.A Bronx Tale also features a strong narrative (in the mould of Goodfellas - I also felt that this film had a touch of Once upon a time in America about it as well). Although it has elements of the aforementioned films, it differs for me in the fact that it focuses more on the conflict that C faces between Lorenzo and Sonny - Lorenzo is his father, but he sees Sonny as a father figure as well. Both Lorenzo and Sonny are on hand to give C advice, but more often than not he chooses to take Sonny's advice over his own father's advice. Goodfellas and OUTIA focused more on the rise within the mob as opposed to ABT focusing more on the conflict that being in a mob can cause within a family - this made A Bronx Tale more of a human story. Now I'm not criticising Goodfellas and OUATIA as I love both of those films, I'm just pointing out that this is a different kind of good mob film.Robert De Niro (like Clint Eastwood) has proved that he is just as good behind the camera as he is in front of it. His direction was superb (the only time it was really a problem was during the bar brawl with the bikers - the camera work for this particular scene wasn't great if I'm honest) In summary, this is a fantastic mob film which has a good narrative and also proves to be an excellent character study. A Bronx Tale is a film I would strongly recommend to everyone.

The movie features Joe Pesci, written by Chazz Palminteri (who also wrote the play) and director Robert De Niro.The movie already has all the elements needed to be a good production.The story is originally an autobiographical one-man show written and performed by Chazz Palminteri.Every time I watch it, I want to watch the play in the theater.

Gritty, real life drama adapted from Palmenteri's hit play about a young Bronx kid growing up in two worlds: The world of hard work and honor as seen through the actions of father, Robert DeNiro (who is exceptional, as actor and director) and a world of money, corruption and danger as seen through the actions of mob boss, Chazz Palmenterri. (who makes Michael Corleone look like a boy scout)The film is beautifully shot, with some snappy editing and a script that moves perfectly with each of the film's sharp characters.Joe Pesci makes a small cameo in the end of the film. One of the best films made in the 90's.

reviews.review_title: I will watch this Whenever I can
reviews.content: I'm going to review the movie "A Bronx Tale" by Robert Deniro. I think you should pay attention to my review because I can give you an accurate score of how good this movie is compared to real life because I live in New York City. Somethings I think this movie did really well was how the displayed the intentional segregation between the two races and the tension between the two.I liked the way Sonny had his business and neighborhood under a tight fist everyone feared him but respected him also.I also liked how each of the two father figures was helping Calogero in his times of need. An example of this would be when Sonny gave Calogero a test to see if the girl he liked was a good kind of girl that he could always have by his side.One thing they could have done better at was to include some other people in the story. Like Calogero's mom came at the beginning and then left.

reviews.review_title: "Gangsters are good guys" isn't exactly a theme for me
reviews.content: There's one big reason that I didn't hate A Bronx Tale, and that's all about the cast. I actually liked Robert De Niro as the straight-laced father, Chazz Palminteri is a spot-on mob boss, and I can even appreciate the somewhat cliched New Yorker performance from Lillo Brancato. Most of the rest of the ingredients thrown together to make this film don't work for me, though. I struggle a great deal with all gangster movies. I can't sympathize with the crooks, and don't find myself rooting for them in any way. Taking a kid and getting him tangled up in their wrongdoing just makes me worry about him and eventually lose sympathy for his situation as he gets himself deeper into the situation.The worst part about A Bronx Tale is that it teased me for a little bit in the first act and had me convinced I was in for a different type of movie. I thought there was going to be a morality tale built in there, and we'd learn how De Niro was always in the right, so the kid should have listened to his father. Instead the film comes dangerously close to condoning the criminal activities of Palminteri's character and his lackeys. By the end it makes it seem like he was a noble man deserving of the protagonist's adoration. There are moments I enjoyed in A Bronx Tale, but it certainly wasn't the type of film I am ever going to watch again. There was a better direction they might have taken that I would have liked, but they simply weren't interested in telling that story.

reviews.review_title: A Bronx Tale is an unforgettable coming-of-age gangster film with values, with a great directional debut and performances, thanks to the brilliant and realistic writing
reviews.content: A Bronx Tale is a gangster and coming of age film which I have wanted to see for many years, and it met my expectations. The film is directed and produced by Robert De Niro, and based on Chazz Palminteri's play. Robert De Niro, who first viewed the play in Los Angeles in 1990, acquired the rights from Palminteri, intent on making the play his directorial debut. The duo then worked heavily together on the screenplay, with Palminteri aiming to retain many of the aspects of the original script, as it was based largely on his own childhood. Notable actors and performances are Robert De Niro as Lorenzo, Chazz Palminteri as "Sonny", Lillo Brancato, Jr. And Francis Capra as Calogero, Taral Hicks, Kathrine Narducci and Joe Pesci. I have to say Robert De Niro and Chazz Palminteri is spectacular in their roles, the latter being my favorite of the leads. Both actors who play Calogero are great! This film actually launched Palminteri's acting career, I've seen him in some films and TV, notably Godfather of Harlem and The Usual Suspects which shows off his phenomenal acting.After witnessing a murder in front of his house, nine-year-old Calogero forms a strong and lasting bond with the Bronx' local gangster Sunny, in spite of his father, Lorenzo's, disapproval. A Bronx Tale delivers a closer inspection of father/son relations, life choices and their consequences. There's a subplot which is full with life and written so well, about Calogero's romantic life.For a directional debut, Robert De Niro does everything right, and you can clearly see who taught him, Martin Scorsese that is. I just love how passionate he was with this project, the story and wanting it to be as true to the source material as possible, even casting Chazz Palminteri as "Sonny". Chazz's real name is actually Calogero and this story is autobiographical. It just says so much as a producer and director on Robert De Niro's side, such great work! This might have been one of the best coming of age movies I've ever seen, maybe it's because of my love for Robert De Niro as an actor and for the gangster genre. But everything feels so real, so human, it's just brilliantly and beautiful written. The themes De Niro brings up in this film is perfect and executed as good. Roger Ebert wrote this in his review which I can only agree with. "A Bronx Tale is a very funny movie sometimes, and very touching at other times. It is filled with life and colorful characters and great lines of dialogue, and De Niro, in his debut as a director, finds the right notes as he moves from laughter to anger to tears. What's important about the film is that it's about values." In 2008, the American Film Institute nominated this film for its Top 10 Gangster Films list, worthy of a place I might add but there are so many excellent gangster films.

Even though Robert De Niro plays a good guy in this movie, he has one heck of a battle with "Sonny" who likes his son and wants to teach him the old "MOB" ways. Eventually, he wins, but I won't tell you how. You HAVE to see for yourself! All the mobsters played their parts to a maximum! Those were the good old days! (Excellent Movie) Ps. Watch for Joe Pesci at the beginning of the movie. (car scene)

Growing up in the Bronx with two Fathers looking over you. One is the real hard working Father who supplies the wisdom of the heart while the other is the local gangster who supplies wisdom from the brain. Great character study but shame about what felt like a rushed ending after a long slow effective build up.

reviews.review_title: DeNiro did an excellent job with his directorial debut.
reviews.content: Although DeNiro's directing eye is strikingly similar to Scorsese's (hm how did that happen) this coming of age tale of a boy torn between to father figures, his bus driving father and the neighborhood wise guy that takes him under his wing, delivers on most cues that make these types of movies some of the best of all time. Not to mention its a time when italians weren't defined by their fist pumping and drunkenness

reviews.review_title: Thank Your Robert De Niro and Chazz Palminteri, Best Movie Ever.
reviews.content: First off, I would like to say that I think "A Bronx Tale" is one of the best movies I have ever seen. As an average movie watcher, this is one of the most emotional movies I have watched.What sticks out for me is the amazing soundtrack, which can really capture the emotion of the scenes, and what I think is an excellent performance by Chazz Palminteri, Robert De Niro, and Lillo Brancato. I wouldn't agree with people expecting it to be another "Goodfellas" or "Godfather", cause this movie is in a category of its own. It is an excellent coming of age story, and you really feel as though you grow up with Calogero(Lillo Brancato) and there is a strong emotional connection to the characters Sonny, a crime boss who takes Calogero under his wing(Chazz Palminteri), and Lorenzo, Calogero's father(Robert De Niro). Now I wouldn't consider this a spoiler, but the ending is probably the most emotional ending I have seen, and it left me so proud of the movie that it motivated me to write this review (My first review). I highly recommend this movie to everyone, whether or not you love gangster films, because I really feel as though it is a gangster movie, the plot involves more of the coming of age of Lillo Brancato's character, and less of the gangster aspect of the story. From what I understand there is also a Broadway play, and I would expect that to be golden as well, but overall PLEASE WATCH THIS MOVIE, it is that good. There are tons of amazing quotes and scenes and this movie leaves you with a deep lesson, which I really didn't experience in Godfather or Goodfellas, but I still consider those movies to be top notch. For this I applaud Robert De Niro and Chazz Palminteri and all the actors involved with this picture, and I hope that more people see this movie and really appreciate it.

Chaz Palminteri and Robert DeNiro both turned in great performances. Palminteri's portrayal of a neighborhood crime boss was very good. He seemed wise but at the same time an emotionally unstable punk. Good production values; it kept you going with the doo-wop and 60's rock soundtrack. Some parts were questionable - no explanation was ever given for the disappearance of C's mother eight years later. When the bikers got beaten up in the bar by a bunch of fat, middle-aged Italians, it didn't seem credible. Biker gang members are tough guys and they got beaten up as if they were defenseless children. C and his friends all wore hats, but I was also in high school in 1968 and nobody wore one of those stupid Frank Sinatra hats. Maybe a knit cap , but that's it. The commentary that DeNiro's character was poor even though he was a municipal bus driver for over ten years was not credible. Bus divers made a decent wage back then. I even know of one who became a millionaire by investing in property. The racism angle was realistic. Neighborhoods were defined by race and there was a lot of mistrust and hatred. The romance between C and Jane seemed believable. Good movie - I would recommend it.

Robert DeNiro's film about a father and his son growing up an in a Italian neighborhood in New York and his son's struggle in growing up around crime, mafia and a Don whom he idolizes (Palminteri) named sonny. Meanwhile his friends experience some tension with black neighborhood thugs as well. The film is done very well, and it intertwines the classic mafia scenarios with a little bit of a father/son relationship as well as interracial love relationship between Calogero and a black love interest from the opposite side of town. i think DeNiro crafted a good film with a great atmosphere. WELL DONE BOBBY! 10/10

This film could potentially be the most underrated 'American/Italian gangster' film out there. Perhaps because the film was so good, I didn't want it to end and felt it could of went on a bit longer. Hindsight is a wonderful thing! A must watch!

De Niro's directorial debut and Palminteri's screenwriting debut. Maybe in some version this smells like a disaster, but in the end we got a very good movie. Both are strong acting names with several excellent film roles, but here each has done double duty, behind and in front of the camera. It looks like a typical gangster movie, I would even say that it is predictable at times, but the movie has a strong story, characters and relationships between them. De Niro is playing literally the complete opposite of what he has done many times in his career, so I found it a bit unusual. The actor who plays his son physically looks overwhelmingly like De Niro's younger version. A film about education, crime, consequences, racism, own choices in life, many topics are squeezed into the barely two hours of the film. Palminteri did a great job in his role as the boss, and I'm sorry that De Niro didn't have a slightly different role, but he's probably nicer in that too. At the end, we have a great cameo role that fits this movie perfectly and I liked it a lot. Definitely a recommendation for filmmakers.

reviews.review_title: A tale from a really dependent kid
reviews.content: Boy was Calogero one messed up kid. Everybody always said "when you're older you'll understand" and just imagine how this affects a person. You just think you're to young to understand, but in fact what happens is you start believing you're too dumb to comprehend those things. And when does the day when you'll be old enough come, anyway. Does a person just wake up and say "tell me, I'll understand". NO, cos' he's too busy trying to figure out who he's going to ask to tie his shoe laces. A person like this becomes so dependent on others because he was raised to keep his mouth shut and just tag along. If this is semi-biographical at least Chaz Palminteri had the guts to show how limited his mind was, because his character seems really dumb. Lilo Brancato is not the best actor in the world, that's for sure, and he made the character look even dumber, especially with the way he walked. De Niro and Palminteri both play their roles well, but no one shines, basically the whole movie could have been better if it were sharper. Worth the watch, especially for some exceptional scenes, but on the whole the movie looks like a PG version of "Goodfellas" meets "Liberty Heights" 7/10

reviews.review_title: De Niro's directorial debut is stunning...
reviews.content: Robert De Niro is known for being a tough talking, intimidating person on the screen. His roles in Goodfellas, Raging Bull, and Casino are proof of that. In his directorial debut, he directs and also plays the part of a loving yet stern father figure who you sometimes feel bad for. It is this story of life growing up in a neighborhood run by a crime boss and how a mans son is almost dragged too deep into it.A Bronx Tale features Chazz Palminteri as the crime boss known as Sonny. Sonny makes Calogero (Lillo Brancato), or as he calls him 'C', his new apprentice. 's father is Lorenzo played by De Niro who doesn't like Sonny and how he runs things. He especially doesn't want his own son being involved in that kind of life. 'C' has been around Sonny since he was nine years old, shooting craps in Sonny's basement. Sonny is now 17 and learning a few tips here and there on how things work in the neighborhood. It's fear that gives Sonny respect and gives him control over the area. 'C' is also forced into some uncomfortable situations with his nitwit friends who want nothing more than to be like Sonny no matter what the cost. When a skirmish between the the nearby black community and these guys, it makes a turn for the worse when 'C' watches his friends beat up some black teenagers. To make matters worse, 'C' has a little crush on a girl at school who happens to be black. He sees nothing wrong with that, other than the fact that no one would accept them in his group. They must keep their love a secret.De Niro does a wonderful job directing this picture. He uses narration by 'C' throughout the entire movie to make it a first-person experience. The story told through his eyes is one that is gripping and keeps you enthralled. Palmintiri is wonderful as Sonny who at times is as kind hearted as a lamb, but then will pounce on you in a second. Sonny's power over the community is brought on by fear. His ability to make a grown man tremble when he looks at you makes him the man he is. The only person who isn't afraid is Lorenzo. They grew up together and know each other, but they do not see eye to eye on much. De Niro's acting in this role is well done. His title of 'C's father figure is slipping away it seems towards Sonny and it eats away at Lorenzo. The conflict with these three men is showcased wonderfully.The story of A Bronx Tale is one that is very entertaining and fulfilling. It shows how one decision you make is the difference between life and death. There are many good lessons to be learned for 'C' in this movie that even can be associated with life today, such as don't get involved with the wrong crowd and listen to your parents. A Bronx Tale is the perfect blend of drama and action that could be compared to Goodfellas. As Lorenzo says, "The saddest thing in life is wasted talent,". To overlook this movie is just that.

"A Bronx Tale" (1993): Starring Robert De Niro, Chazz Palminteri, and other talented actors. Set in 1960-68 Bronx New York, this is the story of one small neighborhood, its residents  good and bad  how they interact, how they learn, who survives, and why. Directed by De Niro, written and produced by Palminteri, this is their baby in every way. It's a gritty yet mythical tale as seen through the eyes of a child, hard working adults, and criminals. The music track may at times be a little heavy-handed in its attempts to nail down a time frame, there are a few small continuity issues, but overall this is an enjoyable, rough film. It reminds me of "Avalon" but with gangsters. That is a simplification, but you get the idea. If you don't, SEE "Avalon" too!

It's 1960 in The Bronx Borough of New York City, when the son of bus driver Lorenzo Anello(Robert DeNiro) is tempted by the money, power, and influence of the local mafia boss, named Sonny(Chazz Palminteri). Lorenzo knows what they're all about and won't stand for it, even going so far as to risk fighting Sonny for the attention of his kid, knowing they could put a hit on him! Talk about tough! Sonny, however thinks of the boy as his good luck charm. Among the lessons Sonny passes along to little Calogero(Francis Capra, then Lillo Brancato) are that it's pointless to enjoy a Yankee game because Mickey Mantle never did anything for him personally. But then again, neither do the boxers and jockeys they get him to watch growing up.Fast forward to eight years later when the boy is now a teenager. With the exception of the collapse of the Yankee Dynasty, time has stopped in that part of the Bronx, and few are willing to accept anything different, like the idea of co-existing with Afro-Americans, the arrival of a standard motorcycle gang, and though not mentioned in the movie, the noble efforts of Robert Moses to solve New York's traffic problems. Our hero nearly gets killed by his own men as they beat up the motorcycle gang who barge in on their turf. He also gets a lot of grief from his peers for falling in love with a girl from a black neighborhood, and some additional grief from that girl and her friends for being in the company of such bigots.Much like "Dead Presidents," and "Everybody's All-American," it's a period-piece with no real point that still catches your interest. It draws you in with nostalgia, picks up a lot of steam, but suddenly falls flat. This doesn't necessarily make it a bad movie. It just leaves you wanting a little more from it. At least is has some amusing scenes like when Sonny throws everyone in the bathroom, so for what it's worth, you might want to give it a shot.

reviews.review_title: An Excellent,Powerful And Underrated Classic . A Terrific Directorial Debut From Robert De Niro.
reviews.content: A Bronx Tale is an excellent,powerful and underrated classic that combines fantastic direction,incredible acting,a great script and a memorable soundtrack. All of those elements make A Bronx Tale an amazing movie that is Robert De Niro and Chazz Palminteri at their best.Based on Chazz Palminteri's one man stage play of the same name and set during the 1960s,A Bronx Tale tells the story of a young man named Cologero(Lillo Brancato,Francis Capra)who is torn between the love for his Bus Driver Father Lorenzo(Robert De Niro)and smooth talking gangster Sonny(Chazz Palminteri). As Cologero goes from his childhood to his teenager years Cologero has to deal with his love and admiration for his Father and Sonny as well as growing up.Released in 1993,A Bronx Tale is a brilliant and unforgettable film that marked the directorial debut of actor Robert De Niro and he could not have picked a better project as his debut giving viewers one of the most underrated movies of all-time. I love the Coming Of Age movie genre because with any Coming Of Age film whether it's a Comedy or a Drama the genre deals with growing up and A Bronx Tale is one of the best of the genre because it mixes together a movie about growing up with Gangsters,violence and gritty streetwise dialog. A Bronx Tale is a movie that is dramatic and meaningful,intense and gripping and at times funny and humorous and it's those elements that make the movie amazing and watchable for 122 minutes because when you watch the film you as a viewer you feel like you are in the Bronx in the 1960s thanks to it's characters. With A Bronx Tale you are taken back to a different time and place. A Bronx Tale is also a movie that is deep and realistic mainly because there is lessons about morality and wasted talent(a common theme that runs throughout the film)while also dealing with themes such as family,love and friendship but is done with a harder edge. The movie also deals with themes such as racism and violence that was going on during the 1960s and it's done in a brutal way that was honest to the times. What makes A Bronx Tale a fascinating movie is the movie's three main characters Cologero,Lorenzo and Sonny. Cologero(the fictional version of Chazz Palmenteri)is a great character that we see going from child to a young adult having to grow up fast whether it's dealing his Father Lorenzo or his friend Sonny or the influence of his neighborhood or his friends with tons of struggles and danger. Sonny is a classic character and Gangster because while he's not necessarily a nice guy and he does some bad things he manages to be a likable person because he's smart with tons of depth. While Cologero loves Sonny and his Gangster lifestyle Sonny tells Coleogero not to be like him and try to survive with an education and smarts rather than have a gun. Cologero's Father Lorenzo is the polar opposite of Sonny's Gangster image because Lorenzo is a bus driver that is a working man that loves his son and tries to teach him about not wasting his talents and not to live the life style that Sonny lives by walking the wrong path. With Cologero,Sonny and Lorenzo it's not about a tug of war between Sonny and Lorenzo over Cologero but about two men trying to raise Cologero on the straight and narrow. A Bronx Tale is often seen as a Gangster film and while A Bronx Tale owes a lot to the genre(such as Martin Scorsese's Goodfellas which was an influence on this film)it's not a Gangster film in a tradition sense as it is more about a young man's conflicts than a group of Gangsters. The violence in A Bronx Tale is brutal and in your face but works and makes an impact when the violence happens. The screenplay by Chazz Palmenteri is terrific and memorable with dialog that is gritty and truthful. Palmenteri based A Bronx Tale on himself and his real life experiences on growing up in the Bronx and when you watch the movie,the characters or hear the dialog everything feels accurate. The ending in A Bronx Tale is outstanding because it gives viewers lessons about life,humanity and bringing the film's themes full circle. A terrific ending.The cast is wonderful. Robert De Niro is excellent and memorable as Lorenzo,a Bus Driver that loves his son. Chazz Palminteri is brilliant and unforgettable as Sonny,with Palminteri being smooth and captivating. Lillo Brancato is terrific as Calogero and has great scenes with De Niro and Palminteri. Francis Capra is wonderful as Young Calogero(Age 9)with Capra bringing the right emotions. Taral Hicks is great and beautiful as Jane,Cologero's love interest. Kathrine Narducci is good and sexy as Rosina,Lorenzo's wife. Clem Caserta does a fine job as Jimmy Whispers,Sonny's right hand man. Joe D'Onofrio(Slick),Louis Vanana(Crazy Mario),Luigi D'Angelo(Aldo)and Dominick Rocchio(Ralphie)do great jobs as Cologero's friends. Joe Pesci is terrific in his cameo role as Carmine an old friend of Sonny.The direction by Robert De Niro is sensational,with De Niro always moving the camera and giving the film a style that is simple but effective. Great direction,De Niro.The soundtrack is outstanding with a collection of classic Rock N'Roll songs that fit the movie perfectly. Amazing soundtrack.In final word,if you love Robert De Niro,Chazz Palminteri or Coming of Age films I highly suggest you see A Bronx Tale,an excellent,powerful and underrated classic that you will watch again and again. Highly Recommended. 10/10.

reviews.review_title: Rousing directorial debut for De Niro!
reviews.content: I wasn't positive that Robert De Niro's directorial debut was necessarily going to be a good one. After all, a great actor does not automatically translate into a great director. But there was no need to worry. 'A Bronx Tale' grabbed hold of me from its opening moments and held me in sway throughout.The screenplay was based on a play by Chazz Palminteri, which surprised me, since the movie moves along briskly and the dialog is never too wordy. Oftentimes when watching an adaptation of a play a moment will occur early on when the characters stand there and talk just a bit too long and you realize the work's origins, but this never happened here.Palminteri also stars as the neighborhood mob boss who takes an interest in a local boy who refused to identify him to police after a murder is committed. The boy, Calogero, or C, is the story's narrator and De Niro plays his father, a bus driver who already has had enough trouble keeping his son away from the lure of the flashy life and easy money that the mob promises. Now his task is even harder.One thing that De Niro the director has going for him is De Niro the actor. He plays one of the most heroic characters I've ever seen as the working man trying to raise a son and keep his family safe in an environment that threatens to corrupt them. This film does more to promote family values than any of the self-righteous, morally superior demagogues who supposedly preach such values today.De Niro obviously learned a lot from working with masters like Martin Scorsese, but he deserves credit for his own skills as well. He might not have complete command of all the directorial techniques Scorsese has, but I honestly enjoyed this picture more than 'Goodfellas.' I think the use of the period's popular songs is done better in 'A Bronx Tale' than in the other film.As some have noted, the interracial love interest might have been unlikely at the time but it's not beyond the realm of possibility and in any case we can allow for a little artistic license. Lillo Brancato and Francis Capra also star as Calogero at ages 17 and 9, respectively. Even if you are tired of mob-themed movies and think you've heard enough Italian-American accents to last a lifetime, you might want to give 'A Bronx Tale' a try anyway; it's that good. Give it five stars or 10 on a scale of 10, this is a first-rate film.

I love all the classic gangster movies: Godfather, Casino, Brasco, Goodfellas, Scarface, etc.A Bronx Tale comes off as an awkward amalgam of the classics that doesn't come together smoothly.The clunky "nostalgic" flavored narration served no real artistic purpose.
It just proved to the audience that the film didn't trust its own ability to convey a story...or it didn't trust the audience to understand the thrust of the story without it being spoon-fed to them.The "good dad, bad dad" moral dilemma was an interesting plot driver but everything else about the film felt forced and contrived.The bi-racial romantic element felt like a forced virtue-signaling to the audience "hey everyone, we love diversity and scorn racism here!'. Bravo.Overall the film felt like a poorly executed attempt at a gangster film that was just too hokey, disjointed and forced to be taken seriously.5/10 stars is a generous rating.

reviews.review_title: Coming of age in the Bronx during the '60s
reviews.content: This film is based on Chazz Palmintieri's childhood growing up in the Bronx in the '60s. I found it a loving, often insightful movie, but I did think that likelihood that Palmintieri's C (excellently depicted by Lilo Brancato and Francis Capra) was so rebellious and close to mob boss Sonny (Chazz Palmintieri) at age nine made it surprising that he was still as close to his father (Robert DeNiro as honest bus driver Lorenzo) at the end of the movie.The music, the setting, and the acting are all very good. The music captures a selection of some great doo-wop and then, as the decade continues, some rock. One gets a sense of the Bronx at that time which, from reading comments here, evokes the time and place quite accurately. The film is directed by Robert DeNiro and it's clear his collaboration with Martin Scorsese has influenced him in his use of music, his depiction of complex characters, and a story which keeps the viewer interested. Robert DeNiro is great as a decent, humble man. Chazz Palmintieri depicts a gangster who does care about his neighborhood, and Taral Hicks is great as a girl with whom C falls in love across the barricades. Very entertaining movie, but I did think that it would have been interesting to track C as he grew up so that we could see how he remained close to his father through the years.

If all directorial debuts were even close to Robert De Niro's work in A Bronx Tale we'd never run out of worthwhile movies. This film is a mix of the timeless battles between good and evil, right and wrong, heaven and hell, black and white. Toss in a liberal dose of peer pressure with a great mix of period music and you have a nearly perfect film. 9 1/2 out of 10!

reviews.content: I've seen the movie, and am now watching it on TV, and it's not the same. Sometime between when it was relesed and now, 2021; the picture quality changed. It looks like 2160, something I'm not used to, yet. Doesn't matter.Somethings should never be changed. The true value in this must see coming of age story is found in its gritty, authentic story line, cinematography and acting done by sensational casting. Robert De Niro and Chazz Palminteri reach deep down and bring to life the core essence of that internal struggle of direction faced by many youth when told to just do the right thing but never told what the right thing is.Growing up poor with parents that make an honest living, Colagero (C) tries to understand his father's life lessons but can't contain his ever increasing curiosity and reverence for the local thugs. After C witnesses a crime and responses to it the way the streets taught him, the neighborhood enforcer (Sunny) takes Colagero under his wing to teach a few life lessons of his own. The methods of each role model may be different but the message is the same.. There are consequences for compromising on integrity and values.For C this fact is something that isn't easily understood without living it first hand. He struggles to balance the only 2 futures presented a neighborhood boy growing up in the Bronx which are a safe mundane pseudo existence or an exciting fast paced lifestyle of money, power and respect.

I loved the use of music in this film.  Whenever the focus was on the young man, popular music of the day played, reflecting his youth.  When a scene featured his father, jazz music played.  Since jazz is usually considered intelligent music, I took this as pointing out the wisdom that the father possessed.  Rat-Pack tunes accompanied Sonny the Mob boss, and his partners in crime; music that reflected love, but played on the tavern jukebox by folks who practiced fear and intimidation.What I didn't get is that the African-American girl would have an "all is forgiven" attitude toward the young man near the end of the movie.  Yes, he saved her brother from getting serious injuries in a racially motivated attack by his friends, but the young man called her brother a ethnic slur in front of her.  Also, the young man's mother just seems to disappear after the first hour of the film.Otherwise, this is a good directorial effort from Mr. DeNiro.

When surrounded by crime your entire life it's not so easy to realize what's good in the world, especially when criminals are being praised. People in power are either loved or feared. reviews.review_title: To be or not to be a gangster
reviews.content: The fascinating thing about this movie is that it cannot simply be classified as yet one another MAFIA gangster story. It is much more than that. In its core, it is a film about allurements and moral issues that a young kid of rather poor descent is facing when growing up in an environment as wild and colorful like the Bronx of the 1960's.On the one hand, the young kid Calogero, the main character, is very much attracted by the sovereignty of Sunny, head of the local MAFIA chapter, whom he does not sell to the police after witnessing Sunny shooting someone on the street. On the other hand, he also feels respect (not always) for his honest father, the bus driver, who does not want to be drawn into the MAFIA affairs and at the same time tries to prevent his son from being drawn into these. This is conflict number one.Both father figures are plaid in a very impressive manner. It is interesting to see Robert de Niro (who also directed the movie) performing very well also in the unusual role as an honest and modest family father whereas Chazz Palminteri (who also wrote the semi-autobiographic screenplay) almost manages to define his part of the big Mafioso as a new benchmark.In conflict number two Calogero has to find his way through his feelings towards a black girl and the hateful attitude of his Italian environment towards the black community in the neighborhood. Hence, the film also serves as a good vehicle to show the great racism issues of the time.There is a few more wise things in the movie that add to its quality like Sunny talking about Machiavelli's theory about availability or Calogero's father talking about wasted talent being the saddest thing in life or tests on whether to dump a girl or not.Unfortunately the film also has a few disturbing elements in it that do not allow it to be among my personal front-runners.**The acting performance of 17-year-old Calogero cannot keep up with the rest of the movie. **The love story between Jane and Calogero is not very convincing. Why should beautiful Jane be attracted by 17-year-old Calogero who is no more than a mediocre guy with a strange hat who is constantly staring at her? **The narrator describes the rockers in the bar beforehand as wild People who are used to bar fights but then they are beaten up by Sunny's loyalty like little boys. **The young Italian fellows of Calogero are pictured in a too simplistic and one-dimensional way. Do young guys really have nothing more in their minds than impressing the world by being ignorant and violent! If so the scene with them throwing their Afro-American district neighbors off their bikes and beating them up is not unnecessary brutal but otherwise ...Besides these flaws, it was maybe also the multiple layers that exist in the movie that prevented it from being a best seller at the cinema box office (if quality has something to do with sales figures at all).On a final note, I also want to mention the beautiful gospel-like theme song right at the beginning and the end of the movie. Besides its beauty it also serves as a perfect vehicle to drive us away quickly from our real environments on to the Bronx of the 1960's.

reviews.review_title: One of the most authentic gangster dramas with a solid script, powerful directing, and brilliant acting
reviews.content: Each great gangster drama offers a unique perspective on the criminal world in general and on what it means to be a gangster in particular.After watching "The Godfather", people might think that being a prominent gangster means being a clever strategist, playing an adrenaline-filled, violent power game with many lives at stake, a seasoned warrior, sacrificing almost everything for the sake of the "family" winning the game.After watching "Scarface", people might think that being a prominent gangster means being an extremely dangerous, crafty, and lucky beast, whose strong intuition and unsurpassed surviving instincts help to ruthlessly devour the less lucky inferior beasts in the explosive acts of a powerful bestial rage.While "A Bronx Tale" might not have the epic dramatic intensity of "The Godfather", or the exuberant energy, tension, and drive of "Scarface", or the mysterious tragic depth of "Once Upon a Time in America", it has that unique perspective that makes a good gangster movie great.One of the key strengths of the film is its authenticity and realism. With all the great competition from the gangster movie masterpieces, "A Bronx Tale" might be one of the closest to capturing the essence of a gangster life and avoiding a dangerous trap of its glamorization and generating any unhealthy excitement about it.The movie skillfully shows that while some violence, some strategy, some rage, and some family values do have their place in a life of a gangster, their significance has been grossly exaggerated by the popular culture.According to "A Bronx Tale", a typical gang member (and even a crime boss) unsurprisingly leads a boring, meaningless, shallow life dominated by fear and a fundamental inability to trust anybody. At the center of the movie is a principal (although mostly indirect) confrontation between a local crime boss, Sonny (Chazz Palminteri, in a powerful and perfectly convincing performance) who befriends a neighborhood kid, and the father of the kid – a local bus driver Lorenzo (Robert De Niro, at his best). True to its focus on realism and authenticity, "A Bronx Tale" does not make Lorenzo a hero, a wise charismatic leader, or a saint without blemish. Lorenzo is a good ordinary man who loves his son, sincerely tries to raise him well, and finds courage to try to shield him from the influence of the gang.A screenplay by Chazz Palminteri skillfully tells a colorful, touching tale full of vibrant realism and serves as a solid, reliable backbone for the movie. While a purist might find some minor issues here and there, (a crime boss citing Niccolò Machiavelli seemed to be a little far-fetched to me) the script is simply outstanding. I am quite sure that ninety-nine percent of the Hollywood screenplay writers will never ever create anything remotely close in quality to this excellent work and therefore should be forever jealous of it.A directorial debut of Robert De Niro was a brilliant success. Oh, how I wish that instead of wasting his talent on the endless "Fockers" sequels and such, he would consider directing more movies and continue exploring this mostly uncharted dimension of his enormous talent.A great actor himself, Robert De Niro was simply amazing in working with the actors on the scene. Under his guidance, all the actors, both well known and unknown, showed such an extraordinary combination of depth and subtleness in reflecting human feelings and emotions, that the only word that comes to mind is "magic". It was a pure magic, created by a genius - Robert De Niro.If you did not see "A Bronx Tale" before, I would highly recommend giving it a chance and watching it, maybe even together with your responsible, mature teenage kids, despite the well-deserved "R" rating. "A Bronx Tale" is not a family movie; it has some strong violence and bad language in it, but it is free from sexually explicit scenes and has surprisingly a lot to say about family values: protecting the loved ones, making wise choices, being faithful, resisting a bad influence, maintaining dignity under difficult circumstances, being respectful, truthful, and accountable.knowyourmovie.blogspot.com

reviews.review_title: DeNiro proves his genius for directing as well as acting.
reviews.content: What a delight.A Bronx Tale is one of those movies that will take your soul for a ride into another world. I grew up in Southern California, but Robert DeNiro and Chazz Palminteri gave me a special gift with this movie. They shared all they loved about growing up in the sixties in New York.Everyone knows that just above the reality of a time and place there lies the surreal and beautiful image it leaves in your mind. Most refer to these memories as the good old days. You know, when you think back at a time you treasure and you forget the pain and the ugliness and all that remains is what made gave it it's magic.We have all enjoyed the films of DeNiro, Scorcese, and their extended neighborhood of filmmakers, and we have heard them talk about their good old days in a place most outsiders fear. Well, Palminteri has crafted a beautiful picture of those days and DeNiro has brought it to life with this wonderful film about morality in a place where immorality was beginning to take hold.DeNiro paints a vision of the Bronx in the good old days, not as it actually was, I suspect, but how it seemed to the young boy who grew into the young man who narrates the film.Told from this boy's perspective, we are whisked through a magical tour of the boy's whole world, the neighborhood. He also introduces us in a hilarious sequence to all of the larger than life neighborhood wiseguys.We grow up with our young protagonist as we all grew up. We see him lose his innocence as the world moves into and his mind reaches out of their small urban paradise.Set to the enchanting and beautifully chosen music of the time and place, we see young Calogero deal with the world around him with the help of the simple hard working moral father played by DeNiro and the King of the neighborhood Sonny, (Chazz Palminteri).One important part of the movie is the tug of war between the father and the godfather over Calogero. They both love the boy, but The Father sees Sonny as immoral and a doorway to Calogero's ruin. What the father can't do however is compete with the power and glamour of Sonny. I mean he is the one guy that everyone "Loves" and he chooses Calogero as someone special to him. The boy is drawn to him like a magnet, partially out of hero worship, partially because it gets the neighborhood thrown at his feet, and partially because he really loves and respects him.This leads to another magical part of the film. Sonny is quite a character. A murderer who isn't all that bad. What do I mean by that? He chose his path early on, and then outgrew it. He stepped into a world of intimidation and violence and grew to hate it, but couldn't walk away now if he tried. A man who is held hostage by his power. He can never trust anyone; he lives his life that he has grown to see as beautiful and full, while knowing he is on borrowed time. He tries very hard to let Calogero know that world is out there, and that the world of gangsters is not the one the boy should choose.A very good scene paints this out for us. Calogero asks Sonny if it is better to be loved or feared. He answers to the effect that it is better to be loved, but that he in his position, he has to choose feared. "It lasts longer"Another pearl of wisdom we get from the immoral moralist is when addressing the blossoming romance with the Nubian beauty Jane played by Taral Hicks. When asked if it was okay for him to date a black girl when all the people around him would be very much against it, Sonny says, "When it is just the two of you together that is all that matters".A Bronx Tale is a very under-appreciated masterpiece. It is a movie that will make you think, while it moves you through a beautiful urban dream.

reviews.content:
The problem with a gangster film featuring Robert DeNiro is the tendency to expect something along the lines of "Goodfellas" or "Casino" or "The Godfather," but you have forget those classics to watch this with an open mind, This is the brainchild of Chazz Palminteri and Robert DeNiro, the latter in the director's chair, and is the story of a bus-driver father trying to raise his son with the American values of hard work, self pride and honesty in a neighborhood where the underground gangsters run a lot of things and have a lot of money. Little Calogero, later "C" witnesses the neighborhood godfather, "Sonny" kill someone and refuses to identify him to the police, after which Sonny takes him under his wing and takes a liking to him as his own in order to teach him his own ways and thinking."The working man is a sucker," his son learns from Sonny, while his dad has to teach him that the working man is the true hero by taking care of his family and never has to look over his shoulder.Little "C" participates in the gangsters' crapshoot game garners a lot of money in tips, which his father finds, and gives it back to Sonny, even to the dismay of his wife, as they are poor and could really use the money.The music entries are executed superbly! Lorenzo (DeNiro) listens to the jazz station on his portable radio, which would have better to have used actual recordings from the '60s Blue Note and Prestige library, instead of using newer recordings made to sound vintage. The soundtrack had no trouble getting the licensing permission to use original '50s and '60s pop recordings, so why not use original jazz recordings? But in the scene on the bus where he first sees his love interest and can't take his eyes off her, they segue from some smooth jazz from the bus driver's radio, to Wilson Pickett's "Ninety-Nine and a Half," which is blasting from the local record shop when they reach the black neighborhood. Later, when C is getting ready for his date with his new love (played by the lovelyTaral Hicks), he looks into the mirror and snaps his fingers to kick off the drums of "Baby, I Need Your Loving" by the Four Tops into the next scene. I love that kind of editing and splicingI
In spite of the violent scenes, the biker scene in the bar, and the Italian youngsters' rage over their black peers riding their bikes through their neighborhood and then later paying for it with their lives, the movie has many touching moments and good morals to teach. No, don't expect a Scorcese knock off, but enjoy it for what it is and not for what you were hoping for.

reviews.content: De Niro is a fierce force behind the camera as well as in front of it. A phenomenal directorial debut by De Niro. De Niro and Palminteri go head to head over De Niro's son. A wonderful story about a kid who has two fathers; the real one being a working man and the other a gangster. The kid studies in two schools too; one normal and the other street school. It beautifully narrates the dilemma created in the kid's mind about life and the correct way towards it. He keeps asking questions to himself. This coming-of-the-age drama does have some Scorsese style but it also finds a new angle of depicting a gangster story.A really powerful and rare movie. The most respectable and perfect second cousin to Goodfellas. Highest Recommendation :)

reviews.review_title: This is it ! my all time number 1 favourite film ever
reviews.content: I have now seen this film about 38 times and i still absolutely adore this instant classic! being a huge De Niro fan and of mafia films too i knew that i would love this and i did. The incredible story by Chazz Palminteri (who also plays Sonny magically in the movie)is great and stays true to it's roots, the tensity shown between the Italian- Americans and the African- Americans and of course the fact that De Niro is in it and It was his first job as director. The Film is about a young boy who grows up in the Bronx streets of New York and after he sees someone killed in front of him by Sonny the 'boss of the neighbourhood' he makes the choice not to tell the police and Sonny immediately takes a liking to the boy. Soon he grows up in to a young man, now with two fathers one his real dad a bus driver (played by Robert De Niro)and the other is Sonny who both tell him which choices he should make in life if he values his future and soon he will find that out the hard way.I myself is still a teenager, but i know what a good film is . This is a perfect film.

The atmosphere of life in the Bronx is so vivid, from the opening credits where "I wonder why" by The Belmont's plays as wee see Doowops on the corner; Italian men romancing their women (which involves screaming MARIE, GET IN THE CAR), kids playing near fire hydrants & men playing baseball in the streets.I loved Calogero's voiceover from his perspective as a child - particularly when he starts hanging around the bar and describes the colourful neighbourhood characters of Eddie Mush (the jinx), Frankie Coffeecake, Tony Toupee, Jimmy Whispers & JoJo the Whale etc.I really enjoyed the relationship between Calogero & Sonny. Sonny was given much more dimension than just the dangerous man Calogero was not supposed to spend time with. Funny, thoughtful and wise, his fatherly connection with 'C' gives a more humanly depiction to an otherwise intimidating gangster. Palminteri was excellent in this role.Of course, De Niro delivers a wonderful performance too. He tries to teach his son not to respect or admire the gangsters he sees on the streets, as they aren't the real tough guys. Playing a bus driver, he represents the working man - who his son is convinced are the suckers of the world. Although it takes many years and a few tragedies along the way for Calogero to comprehend this, he finally comes to respect his father.Alongside Calogero's leap to manhood, the film also depicts young love, peer pressure, and the racial tension simmering between Italians and Blacks during the 1960's.Small things I liked: The Car Door Test, Calogero going to confession, Sunny reversing the car and a young Calogero imitating Sunny.I would have liked to have seen what Calogero's 'talent' amounted to, since this is one of the most recognised quotes of the movie, but maybe that's just me being picky.
Nevertheless, with music which compliments the mood of the film (expect iconic songs from Sinatra, The Kinks, Jimi Hendrix, James Brown, The Beatles & The Flamingos)- A Bronx Tale is a major success for Robert De Niro's directorial debut.

I've only just seen this having managed not to for years. Its very good indeed and certainly kept me watching.However, I enjoyed the 1960 part more than the 1968 part. And it did seem a bit 'forced' at times. Also - why hasn't anyone else mentioned Goodfellas?! Just after it started I was thinking "Goodfellas" all the time. Its very similar indeed - especially at the start. Not that this in necessarily a bad thing but the resemblance was uncanny - and I notice this came out only 3 years after Goodfellas too! I also noticed a bit of a nod to Once Upon A Time in America from time to time too - again, not a bad thing at all.All in all - don't expect a 10/10 classic like Goodfellas or Once Upon A Time in America and just watch it with an open mind. I think some of the 10/10 reviews here are a little over the top. And its way better than anything De Niro has been in for the last 12 years of course (needless to say).

6 October 2000A Bronx Tale starring Robert DeNiro and Directed by Robert DeNiro. 1993 was the year he unveiled a hidden secret of his. His directorial debut feels like it's made by Scorsese which isn't surprising, he influenced many directors with his unprecedented detail to storytelling. Gangster films have a grittiness and hard-boiled presence that they own so dearly. Unfortunately this genre possesses the word repetition, certain movies feel too similar to each-other.The main protagonist is Calogero, a teenager living in the Bronx in the 60s. The character is not that interesting and his performance is just fine. In the beginning of the film we get introduced to a 9 year old version of Calogero, the child actor is infuriating to tolerate and his constant mischief only amplifies my frustration to a level that genuinely annoyed me. I understand that it's his role and it's all part of the story but there are so many negative aspects about this child's performance that can easily put someone off the film. Let me talk about one for instance, you'll have to put subtitles on because you can never understand a word this kid is saying, he is mumbling everything that comes out of his mouth. He also talks extremely fast so if you understand any of his lines whilst watching the film for the first time then I'll be surprised. An hour into it and finally we get to change time frame, 1960 to 1968. Calogero is now a 17 year old teenager, this version of the character is far superior, First of all you understand everything he's saying. He has a good emotional range, he can act well during heartfelt sequences and he is overall a better actor when compared to his predecessor.Robert DeNiro as usual is amazing and his sympathetic and concerned character is definitely the high spot of the film for me personally. The untouchable love he has for his son feels authentic and very legitimate. I felt sorry for him and all of his issues, stepping into his son's shoes and making his life easier was an idea I had in mind during the film. Chazz Palminteri was decent, it was an easy performance to pull off. He is used to having these types of roles constantly handed to him. The movie's plot is painfully average and it concludes with a terrible ending. The camerawork is special at times, especially the shots of Bronx during the night. That's about it when it comes to cinematography, the entire movie has a damp and unsettling look. It seems as if the colours have been faded out and it creates this rusty, metallic look to the scenery which is very ugly to look at. The racial discrimination was an interesting topic to delve into and I also enjoyed the story of our protagonist's black girlfriend, it was hard to have a girlfriend with a different colour of skin in the 60s. Racism was evolving and becoming a very serious matter. The segment of the intolerant teenagers gunning down the store filled with black people and then throwing molotovs to it so they could create a dangerous fire was adequate but when they got one of their molotovs thrown back at them it became quite intriguing. It was a classic example of "what goes around, comes around".The ending is terrible, it's an easy way out. We had a heated rivalry between Robert DeNiro and Chazz Palimentiri that was actually starting to amount to something vast and important but then one of them dies. Killing someone doesn't add anything interesting to the story, there's no proper meaning behind it. The gunman is unbelievably insignificant to the main plot. They cut away all the tension because of a useless death scene that results to nothing. I would've preferred if our protagonist chose himself the person he wanted to stick to instead of some purposeless scene automatically do the job for him. An unsatisfactory ending that leaves me dispirited. It's a happy ending for my favourite character but the lead up to the cherished moment was very badly doneI moderately recommend A Bronx Tale, Robert DeNiro's character is great and the racial discrimination was intriguing. Everything else was either flawed or just not that special to me. However, I was attracted to see a movie that DeNiro directed. Overall, it has it's problems but it can still be enjoyed by the casual viewer's eye.

Yes, it's another gangster film -- of sorts -- but it reminded me also of the series "Friday Night LIghts" because it's ultimately about values and the choices people make based on their values. And, of course, the values are not static but evolve. I found the acting to be excellent all around. It was especially interesting to see DiNiro in a sympathetic role. A side benefit for auto geeks is the wonderful display of 1960s cars, especially the Caddies. It's too bad that Lillo Brancato fell into drugs and crime himself, including incarceration. Supposedly, he is now clean and acting again. He's quite good.

I was left feeling sad at the end but its a great, well told movie.A Bronx Tale makes my all time top ten movies.10/10

This was Robert DeNiro's directorial debut. I've read after seeing the play on off-Broadway in 1990, DeNiro asked Chazz Palminteri for the film rights, which he agreed to in exchange for the starring role in the film. Due to both the critically and commercially successful run of the play and film respectively, Palminteri revived the play and took it on tour in 2007 where I was able to meet him and see his play in Tucson, AZ. I put A Bronx Tale right up there with Casino and Goodfellas. It reflects the mafia in a way no previous films of its time had. There's lots of humor and life lessons alike. Chazz told me and in many other interviews it's loosely based on a variety of situations he was exposed to as a child growing up in the Bronx. It has a very humorous side, but can also be serious in it's story. This movie is quite a rewarding watch! Reviewed by AN/NR 11-14-11

A Bronx Tale is a gangster drama film. It shows a different side of gangster films, more heart and romance. This film takes you into the life of one kid, we watch Calogero from when he was young to when he gets a little older. Calogero grows up in the Bronx at a time when there is a lot of violence going on and at a time of racial tension. The battle this character fights is his regular life with his hardworking father and his other life as a wanna be mobster. The head of the mafia Sonny takes care of Calogero as if he were his own son. This film is great, it has a lot of action scenes that I thought were very realistic. The first time director Robert Dinero wanted to tell a story about a kid torn apart in life not knowing which way to go or where he is being pushed. A softer side of a gangster flick showing real emotions of these gangsters, it makes them look more real and true to life because gangsters have feelings too. From beginning to end the director effectively showed the racial tension and the main characters struggles through his regular family and his gangster family. A great picture for the first time director Robert Dinero.

I'll start by saying that this is one of the best films of the 90's and is criminally overlooked. And then I'll attempt to justify that statement, but the film is the only real justification. Robert De Niro's directorial debut is a deeply absorbing film about a kid growing up in Little Italy, New York, and the effect that the neighbourhood, in particular a mafia boss has on him. De Niro plays Lorenzo Anello, the honest, hard working father of Calogero, played by two actors: Francis Capra at age 9, and Lillo Brancato at age 17. Calogero, or "C" as he is later nicknamed, is interested by the man who runs the bar a couple of doors down, Sonny, played by Chazz Palminteri(who also wrote the play it was adapted from, and the screen play. It is also based on his upbringing). This interest grows hugely early on in the film when C witnesses Sonny shooting a man in the street, it seems like over a parking space. Later that day C is asked by the police to identify the shooter, but C doesn't rat him out. And what this does is make Sonny, the Mafia Boss, interested in C. As the film plays out, C gets more and more attached to Sonny, who sets him as good an example as you can expect from such a man, and this attachment worries Lorenzo. It worries him because he wants C to be "a real man" and work an honest job, but realises he is slipping towards crime. This is not a crime film, but I think it suffers because thats what people expect it to be. This is a film about how the neighbourhood that a boy who grows up in affects his coming of age. And it is the whole neighbourhood, not just Sonny. He is the biggest influence, but other things that affect C in a big way are the racical hatred that his friends show towards black people, and the way his Dad tries to get him to be, as a result of what he knows goes on around there. The setting is very similar to the start of Goodfellas, but unlike that film, this one shows the neighbourhood in a lot more detail, and in a way the 'hood is the main factor in the film. Whereas Goodfellas is concerned with 3 guys' journey through crime, Bronx Tale is concerned with the effect of the neighbourhood, particularly Sonny, on a person's evolution. The film is made wonderfully, with a good script and great acting, but I think the real kudos should go to De Niro's direction, because he really brings the setting and the mood alive, through well planned sets and locations, and a fantastic soundtrack. I have heard critics say this is not at all original, and when you think that you will have seen similar things in Goodfellas, I suppose it isn't, except in one way. And that is what I have already mentioned. The Godfather was about family. Goodfellas was about low end Mob crime.Mean Streets was about small time hoods. This is about the environment around you and how that will make you "understand", something that C is continually told he will when he is older, and eventually does. The fact that it has similarities with many other films is by the by because it couples this with a refreshing philosphical take on many diffrent things. It deserves to be treated as a masterpiece, and thats how I think of it. 5/5 and a huge round of applause.

reviews.review_title: De Niro and Palminteri combine for excellence,
reviews.content: This is an interesting movie because it tackles two topics in one shot: the lure of the glamorous life of crime and the state of racism in the 1960s."A Bronx Tale" shows Calogero Anello, a young Italian living in the Bronx, faced with both of these issues. His childhood idol is a violent crime boss (Palminteri), while his friends, along with nearly everybody in his neighborhood, are racist. Meanwhile, he takes a liking to a black girl, and his honest father (De Niro) tries to keep him away from the crime syndicate and instill working class values in him. What choices will Calogero make and how will they affect his future? De Niro and Palminteri both give outstanding performances. The plot is not riveting, but is still interesting enough to keep the viewer involved. Rather than plot devices or complicated story lines, the film keeps us engrossed with character interactions and emotions. Calogero strikes me as being a little stupid, although not as stupid as his friends. I suppose this is necessary, however. A really intelligent person (like De Niro's character) would find ways to avoid becoming embroiled in all the neighborhood goings-on.It is frightening to think that racism was so rampant so few years ago, and saddening to think it still exists. "A Bronx Tale" does a fine job of illustrating that no good comes from hate.

Robert De Niros directing debut in which he also features in, is a all in all very good picture. I would recommend it to fans of both De Niro and gangster flicks alike thou don't go in expecting a Goodfellas, Godfather type movie because that it is not. Its quite different then the majority of films in this genre. It follows 'C' from being a 9 year old kid from the Bronx witnessing a murder committed by the towns main man 'Sonny' who then takes 'C' under his wing when he doesn't snitch. Thou 'C'dad (De Niro) doesn't like his son hanging around with him one bit. Thou despite his best efforts several years pass 'c' is now in his late teens and closer to Sonny then ever. So you think this is going to be a rivelry story between C's real father and Sonny his father figure but it only touches on that sub plot a couple more times and its not really made into a big deal. Then it becomes a sort of 'Romeo and Juliet' type romance when 'C' falls for a girl from the African-American side of town which then brings on a tale of racism and conflict.In short this is a very good film, the acting is well done, the 60's era its set in is very realistic and features some great music. Thou it chops and changes a few times the plot line in general is enjoyable. But like I say don't go into this thinking just because De Nero directs and features in the film its going to be a masterpiece. In fact I think his performance is a little disappointing for his great standard, it shows that his main focus was the directing (which is very well done)as opposed to acting. I felt that his scenes didn't have much heart to them despite the importance of the father to son scenes. Its actually the man who plays Sonny that steals the show for me I was captivated every time he came on screen, he managed to be humorous (the 'dice throwing' scene is hilarious), caring yet at the same time very unpredictable.I think if your a fan of the Gangster type movie in general you will like this movie, the romantic side of it may or may not be to your liking. Its enjoyable and worth a watch so I do recommend you give it a go at least.Oh and if you're just watching it for Joe Pesci don't bother hes in it for about 2 minutes which was a bit disappointing he wasn't in it for longer.Hope you enjoy it!

reviews.review_title: Is it better to be loved, or feared?
reviews.content: Robert Deniros took his time, and spent arduous amounts of effort in his first film directed, and it shows. A brilliant piece of storytelling that touches upon the issues prevalent at the time, and a plot that reveals itself only until the last minute.What I particularly liked about the film was the depth of the characters, a trait that is often overseen in today's Hollywood movies. The characters themselves are the most powerful symbols in the movie. The main character, "c", is influenced by two distinct male roll models. The hard working, dutiful father (deniro) who doesn't have much, but worked hard and earned everything that is his. The other male role model, sonny (Palminteri), is the symbol of crime and extortion, the guy that runs the neighborhood. Money floats like liquor, and everything seems all too easy. But sonny has a soft spot for "c", and his preachings to the young and wise contrast with the stiff, rugged lectures of his father. The discord evident between the influences to young "c" leads to a captivating, wonderful story of the childhood and education, both in school and on the streets, of a young child in the Bronx.

reviews.review_title: Robert De Niro as the warm-hearted working man
reviews.content: I liked this movie in the fact that you saw a different side of De Niro. He played a man who would give anything for his family and worked hard in a low paying job instead of being a rich mobster. During the movie De Niro's character proved more than once that he didn't need the mob's dirty money to succeed. He once took back $600 that the street boss Sonny gave to his son. Another time he was offered $150 a week to deliver numbers to people and turned it down. and though his son and his wife give him crap about not taking his chances with the mob, he keeps on keepin on.A couple things bothered me about the movie though. The major one being that you didn't know who to side with in the movie. Here you have the good-guy Lorenzo (De Niro's character) who is working hard to keep his son off the street, and then you have the semi-villain Sonny (Chazz Palminteri) who is teaching Calogero or "C", the main character, how to live on the streets but stay out of trouble. So Sonny isn't really teaching C to do bad things and when he does, Sonny slaps him around a bit. But they try to make Sonny out to be a good guy/bad guy and it doesn't really fly to well. Another thing that bothered me was the mother disappeared in the middle of the movie with no explanation.Some other thing I thought were cool in this movie was the choice of music, which was not just your classic mob stuff (Sinatra, etc.) but they used soul and R & B, which was cool. Another thing I liked was the Inter-racial relationship between Jane and C. You don't see stuff like that in many movies, especially mob movies set in the late 1960'sAll in all, this movie was fun and interesting to watch. I thought it was better to watch it on TV too because they say the F-word about ever 2 seconds. So anytime your bored or feel like an uplifting mob-type movie, rent this and see the other side to mob movies.

reviews.review_title: A great directorial debut for De Niro
reviews.content: This movie presents a warm tale about the struggles of a young Italian American boy growing up in the Bronx in the 60's. His rebellion against his father (De Niro), his striving for acceptance by a mafioso boss, his affections towards an African American girl and his duties to his Italian friends all culminate in a dramatic ending which nicely wraps up the whole bronx tale. Forget other ignorant comments by users who were disappointed that it wasn't a gangster movie or who don't think the interracial relationship was realistic (yet they admit they weren't even alive during the 60's!). This is a great movie, and any comments saying otherwise are plain rubbish.
